They also seem to both be clueless about the problems plaguing their cities; the well-intentioned but gullible Laila is constantly misled by her corrupt advisors, while Igmund seems to be in utter denial *despite* his advisors.

[Unwitting Instigator of Doom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnwittingInstigatorOfDoom): Asking Ulfric for aid against the Forsworn and promising the restoration of Talos worship for it was the key incident that really began the Stormcloak rebellion. When asked about it now, he admits it was a really dumb move and chalks it up to just hoping the Thalmor wouldn't find out.
[Unwitting Pawn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnwittingPawn): To the Thalmor, inadvertently perpetuating their hidden agendas.
[You Killed My Father](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouKilledMyFather): His father, Jarl Hrolfdir, was killed during the Markarth Incident trying to negotiate with the Forsworn.

[Almighty Janitor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AlmightyJanitor): Brina may be just an old soldier trying to live out her retirement, but it's her the townsfolk of Dawnstar look to for leadership, rather than their bratty Jarl. Should the Legion takeover the Pale, however, this is [subverted](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SubvertedTrope) as she's given *de facto* authority as the new Jarl.

[But Not Too Foreign](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ButNotTooForeign): She has an Imperial surname and mentions that she wasn't born in Skyrim, but she's still Nord enough to call the land her home and serve as Dawnstar's Jarl.

[My Country, Right or Wrong](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyCountryRightOrWrong): Has her problems with the Empire's handling of things and recognizes that even an Imperial victory in the civil war won't fix everything overnight, but as a former soldier she's still devoted to protecting the Empire and maintaining peace and order within it.

[Pet the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PetTheDog): As Jarl, she recognizes that her court-mage Madena is a [Shell-Shocked Veteran](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShellShockedVeteran), so gently asks her if she'd be comfortable with providing aid to any wounded soldiers that come in with her Restoration magic, a job she gratefully accepts. In contrast, Skald kept pressuring Madena to fight for the Stormcloaks as a battlemage against her repeated objections.

[Platonic Life-Partners](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlatonicLifePartners): With her housecarl, Horik Half-hand. However, the game code indicates that their relationship might not be as platonic as suggested, because their relationship value is actually set at +4 - lovers.

[Retired Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RetiredBadass): She had to have done *something* to earn the [undying loyalty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UndyingLoyalty) of Horik Halfhand, to the point where he is her housecarl after retirement... not to mention to have reached the rank of Legate regardless.

[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): Especially compared to her [Stormcloak-aligned predecessor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LeeroyJenkins). Everyone in Dawnstar already looked to her for leadership, given Skald's verified reputation as a spoiled brat in an old man's body; and being a retired Legate, she knows her stuff, particularly in terms of guard/troop allocation.

[This Is Gonna Suck](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThisIsGonnaSuck): Her assessment of a possible dragon attack. Dawnstar is completely exposed, the buildings are all made of wood, and arrows are in short supply.

[Corrupt Corporate Executive](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CorruptCorporateExecutive): As owner of the Black-Briar Meadery. Your first special job for the Thieves' Guild involves her hiring you to sabotage a competing meadery in Whiterun.

[Distaff Counterpart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DistaffCounterpart): To Thongvor Silver-Blood. Both are the head of commercially successful families whose success is due to shady and illegal dealings (Thieves' Guild and Dark Brotherhood in Maven's case; mercenaries to bully mine owners and  (SPOILER) Forsworn assassins  to silence enemies in Thongvor's case). Both are replacement Jarls for their respective hold should the other faction take over. In both cases, they have so much influence in the hold and have bribed the local guards so successfully that they arguably [have more power over the town than the rightful Jarls do](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IOwnThisTown). Additionally, both have goons in town who will warn the player of their respective family's influence over the town (Maul and Yngvar the Singer respectively) and said goons become housecarls if Thongvor / Maven become Jarl. The main points of difference are that Thongvor *doesn't* lead his family's business (while he is the eldest and head of the family, his brother leads the business side of things); he isn't explicitly involved in any of the family's illegal dealings; he doesn't have nearly as much direct influence over Jarl Igmund as Maven does Laila; and unlike Maven, he *does* go into exile if the Imperials take Markarth back from the Stormcloaks. Lastly, it's possible for a Stormcloak-allied Dragonborn to become Thane of the Reach after Thongvor becomes Jarl <sup>note </sup>  if they weren't Thane beforehand , but an Imperial-aligned Dragonborn won't have the opportunity to become Thane of the Rift <sup>note </sup>  again, if they hadn't been given the title prior  from Maven if they don't have a high enough favor with her.
[Do Wrong, Right](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DoWrongRight): She didn't jail Sibbi for murder. She jailed him for doing it in public.
[The Don](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDon): Effectively runs crime in [Riften](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WretchedHive).

[Equal-Opportunity Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EqualOpportunityEvil): She can be overheard at the Thalmor embassy party expressing contempt for how Ulfric treats the Dunmer in Windhelm, and she herself trusts a Dunmer to run her meadery.

[Even Evil Has Standards](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvenEvilHasStandards): She is somewhat disgusted by Ulfric's treatment of the Dunmer.
    - If one escapes from the Ratways during "A Cornered Rat" and didn't kill all of the Thalmor, she'll immediately join the rest of the town in slaughtering the remaining agents, suggesting she shares the rest of the town's disdain for them.

[Faux Affably Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FauxAffablyEvil): Maven affects an air of civility and friendship to those around her, but she turns positively acidic in private. For example, when warning Haelga to not practice her "Dibellan arts" on Hemming, Maven bluntly tells her that if she tries it, she will have someone mutilate Haelga's face.

[Hate Sink](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HateSink): Maven uses her connections to the Dark Brotherhood and Thieves' Guild to intimidate and kill anyone who opposes her, is probably the direct cause of Riften being a [Wretched Hive](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WretchedHive), and is generally smug, condescending, and rude to everyone, even if the player  (SPOILER) becomes leader of both those factions . It's pretty clear players are not supposed to be fans of hers.

[Hyper-Awareness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HyperAwareness): Maven is *sharp*. If you're infiltrating the Thalmor Embassy without have joined the Thieves' Guild, she'll have no idea who you are - but she'll immediately figure out that you're not who you *say* you are, and advise you to avoid her for the rest of the party to keep your cover from being blown.

[I Own This Town](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IOwnThisTown): The Black-Briars already control Riften; the Imperials just make it official, which she even lampshades by commenting she's always been the one in charge, the title of Jarl is merely a formality. But if you  (SPOILER) complete both the Thieves' Guild and Dark Brotherhood questlines, *you* effectively control much of what she needs to stay in power.

[Incest Subtext](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IncestSubtext): By pure accident. Hemming is her son, and Ingun and Sibbi are meant to be her grandkids. But she shares a bed with Hemming and people in the game refer to Sibbi and Ingun as her kids (including Ingun herself, who explicitly refers to Maven as her mother).

[Jerkass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Jerkass):
    - Despite relying on the Dark Brotherhood and Thieves' Guild for much of her power, she bosses them around as she believes they cannot survive without her backing, and she uses them to undermine competitors and expand her power further without caring who gets in the way. Her interactions with her own family indicate that she sees them more as employees than blood relatives; and for a [Kick the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KickTheDog) moment, she sneers that the Blessing of Mara you give her will serve her well as kindling for the hearth. - If one didn't become Thane before the Imperials took the Rift, she won't offer the player the chance to complete "The Raid" and then become Thane if they don't have high enough favor with her, fearing the player might attempt to become [The Star Scream](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheStarScream) and take her place. This is in spite of the fact that if it wasn't for the Dragonborn's actions, *she wouldn't be Jarl in the first place*. For comparison's sake, with the exception of Vignar Gray-Mane note  only because the player becomes Thane of Whiterun though the main quest , all the other replacement Jarls on both sides will still allow the player to become Thane after they take over note  and in the cases of Thongvor, Brina, Kraldar, and Brunwulf, they'll let you skip the quest the Jarl they replaced would've required you to do beforehand - and while Vignar does strip you of your title after he takes over, he at least gives you a chance to earn it back by buying Breezehome and helping the people of Whiterun.

[Karma Houdini](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KarmaHoudini): Despite being [The Don](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDon) who fancies herself queen of the underworld via the Thieves' Guild and Dark Brotherhood, there is nothing the player can do to stop her. Due to [Gameplay and Story Segregation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameplayAndStorySegregation), (SPOILER) becoming the Thieves' Guildmaster and becoming leader of or wiping out the Brotherhood does nothing to decrease her power. Furthermore, she becomes Jarl if you side with the Imperials; if you turn Riften over to them during "Season Unending" and later retake Riften for the Stormcloaks, she remains in the city rather than being exiled. Also, because she's a potential Jarl and needed for questlines, she's marked as permanently essential and cannot be killed. The only things the player can do against her that the game recognizes, like stealing Frost or burning too many hives at Goldenglow, she brushes off as minor nuisances.
    - The player can however take a series of specific actions and quest decisions, [outlined here](https://old.reddit.com/r/skyrim/comments/8u8qp3/every_way_to_screw_maven_blackbriar_over/), that screw Maven over, if they want her to get at least some shit. - Presumably she *would* have been taken down at least a peg or two if Mjoll's quest to eradicate the Thieves' Guild had not been cut from the game, since Maven is a particular thorn in Mjoll's side. However, since the quest never made it to the finished game, we never see Maven get any comeuppance.

[Kicked Upstairs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KickedUpstairs): The one silver lining about making her Jarl is that she stays on her throne all day and will no longer go around town harassing people (yourself included).

[No Historical Figures Were Harmed](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoHistoricalFiguresWereHarmed): She won her wealth through bribery, corruption, and murder. Her sons are both [Entitled Bastards](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EntitledBastard) who dislike each other, and one of them is [Ax-Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AxCrazy) to boot. Her daughter is a [Master Poisoner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MasterPoisoner)-in-training who otherwise isn't as bad as the rest of the family. There's even a hint of possible incest. They're the Borgias in the setting.

[Pet the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PetTheDog): Despite her iron criminal grip on Riften, she is the only one capable of hiring Dunmer workers in a city that is borderline fanatically loyal to the Stormcloaks, and none of them have any legitimate complaints about her, although Indaryn and she may have a bit of a tiff.
    - If you manage to become the Guildmaster of the Thieves' Guild before tackling "Diplomatic Immunity" and Maven shows up at the party, you can persuade her to cause a distraction, and she'll do it for you as a favor even though she's fairly certain she doesn't want to know why you need it. - According to the Official Game Guide, Maven funds the Honorhall Orphanage in Riften. Whilst this is likely out of simple [Villain with Good Publicity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainWithGoodPublicity)-based pragmatism, it's still surprisingly nice of her.

[Pragmatic Villainy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PragmaticVillainy): She had her son Sibbi jailed for killing a man, but it wasn't for the deed itself - it was because he did it in public, which is bad for their image and tougher to cover up. His "jail time" is a glorified time-out in a posh cell for not being more discreet in his misdeed.

[The Queenpin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheQueenpin): Played with. She has ties to the Empire and the [Dark Brotherhood](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MurderInc), is a patron of the Thieves' Guild, and is effectively the one who controls Riften... but she doesn't lead any of the groups and is only able to "control" them through the money she funnels from her meadery to them.
[Shock and Awe](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShockAndAwe): She uses lightning spells if threatened, making her the only Jarl to use magic.

[Slouch of Villainy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SlouchOfVillainy): "The throne suits me, doesn't it?" [Subverted](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SubvertedTrope) in that she uses the same posture on the throne as every Jarl not named Elisif.

[Strong Family Resemblance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StrongFamilyResemblance): Like Idgrod, Maven's daughter Ingun looks like her sans a few decades.<!--* TokenEvilTeammate: One of two for the Imperials.-->

[The Unfettered](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheUnfettered): She tells you point-blank when first sent to her that when it comes to business, only two things matter to her - was the job done, and was it done properly. Anything else is meaningless.

[What Happened to the Mouse?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatHappenedToTheMouse): Despite having several children, her husband is never seen nor mentioned, nor whether or not he would have had any role in building her massive mead empire. Several contradictions on how the Black-Briars are related, <sup>note </sup>  The data files and Hemming himself says that Ingun and Sibbi are Hemming's children, while other citizens of Riften claim that Hemming is their sibling  and the fact that Hemming and Maven share a bed, suggests that Hemming was originally supposed to be her husband but was later changed to the role of her son.
[Blue Blood](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlueBlood): Hails from a long line of nobility and, due to the Great Collapse, may possibly be its last remaining member.

[Extreme Doormat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ExtremeDoormat): [Downplayed.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DownplayedTrope) Kraldar's not a complete push-over or a bad Jarl, but he could benefit from being a little more assertive. His response to his Steward all but telling him Savos Aren has ignored all his requests for a meeting is to simply say he must be busy and to try again later.

[Foil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foil): To Korir. They are the last of Winterhold's nobility, and both dearly love their hold and want to see it restored to its former glory. But while Korir blames and resents the mages for his city's ruination and insists Winterhold would be better off without them, Kraldar defends the College and wants to work with them and the Empire to one day revive Winterhold.
[Nice Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceGuy): He's to Winterhold what Brunwulf Free-Winter is to Windhelm.
[The Pollyanna](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThePollyanna): While everyone else left in Winterhold has become jaded and bitter about their prospects, Kraldar remains upbeat about his city (er, town).

[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): Rather than lament the lost glory of Winterhold and despise the Mages like Korir, he acknowledges that the College is the only reason that the city even still exists and believes that amicable relations with them are essential for their prosperity. He's also more proactive, wanting to work with them and the Empire to rebuild Winterhold.
[Wide-Eyed Idealist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WideEyedIdealist): He genuinely believes that Winterhold can be restored to its former glory.

[Armor-Piercing Question](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArmorPiercingQuestion): Asks the player, rhetorically, if the White-Gold Concordat *really* saved the Empire, or just planted the seeds for a second war as has happened with the Stormcloaks.
[Cool Old Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolOldGuy): One of the nicest people in Skyrim and a [Retired Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RetiredBadass) to boot.

[Foil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foil): Oddly enough, to Dengeir. Both are on the older side of their faction's replacement Jarls, are far more critical of their respective faction in some form <sup>note </sup>  Brunwulf will ask if the White-Gold Condordat was what caused the Civil War; Dengeir will fully admit that he only sides with Ulfric over the Empire because Ulfric actually lives in Skyrim, and doesn't actually trust Ulfric , and are appointed to their positions because of their previous occupation. However, Brunwulf is a former soldier, whereas Dengeir used to be Jarl of Falkreath; Dengeir prefers to return to the occupation he previously held, while Brunwulf is rather reluctant to take up the position of Jarl.

[The Good King](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheGoodKing): Perhaps the nicest Jarl in all Skyrim. Within hours of assuming his post he meets with the local Dunmer and vows to spend the city coffers on renovating the ghetto-like Grey Quarter, and also find a way to rehouse the Argonian dock workers. He allows the Temple of Talos to stay open, lets most of Ulfric's court staff keep their jobs, and offers lodgings for the Jarls who supported the defeated Stormcloaks. He remains [Modest Royalty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ModestRoyalty) throughout.

tropeName: I Did What I Had to Do
tropeNotes: [I Did What I Had to Do](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IDidWhatIHadToDo): He dislikes being heralded as a "war hero" by many in Windhelm, admitting that all he did during the Great War was kill a lot of High Elves and not die, something he doesn't regard as particularly heroic.

[Knight in Sour Armor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KnightInSourArmor): He isn't too optimistic about the prospects of improving relations between the Nords of Windhelm and non-Nords, but that doesn't mean he won't try.
[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): Who would have thought a man named "Free-Winter" would be the one to champion equal rights for non-Nords in Windhelm?

[Modest Royalty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ModestRoyalty): Despite his status as a respected war hero (and possibly Jarl), Brunwulf is quick to dismiss any praise as unwarranted and focuses his efforts on aiding the downtrodden.

tropeName: My Species Doth Protest Too Much
tropeNotes: [My Species Doth Protest Too Much](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MySpeciesDothProtestTooMuch): Holds disdain for the "Skyrim for the Nords" notion.

[Nice Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceGuy):
    - Even before becoming Jarl, he will pay the Dragonborn to get rid of bandits who are targeting Dunmer and the Khajiit caravans because the bandits know that Ulfric will do nothing about it, since the victims are not Nords. - Like Ulfric, he refuses to use the term "common rabble" when declaring the player Thane of Eastmarch. - He leaves Windhelm's Temple of Talos untouched and unlocked, and doesn't appear to persecute its priests.
[No True Scotsman](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoTrueScotsman): He hangs a lampshade on the trope, decrying its use by the Stormcloaks.

[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): Within *hours* of getting his new job, he's already met with the dark elves of the ghetto-like Gray District to develop renovation plans, and is seeking a way to let the Argonians into the city without increasing the town's already huge racial tensions. He even keeps most of Ulfric's staff on hand since they know their jobs well enough, and offers lodging to the deposed Jarls who were supporting Ulfric. Much like with Balgruuf, many Imperial-aligned players say that putting Brunwulf on the Windhelm throne is one of the reasons that they back the Empire.
[Reluctant Ruler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReluctantRuler): He much preferred being a soldier to being Jarl, as things were so much simpler and clearer.
[Retired Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RetiredBadass): He fought in the Legion during the Great War.

[Shell-Shocked Veteran](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShellShockedVeteran): Shows signs of this.
QUOTE **Brunwulf**: They call me a war hero. I'm no hero, I'm just a soldier who didn't want to die.<br data-format="\\"/>**Brunwulf**: There's no glory in war. It's just something they tell soldiers so they'll risk their lives.<br data-format="\\"/>**Dragonborn**: That dark elf called you a war hero.<br data-format="\\"/>**Brunwulf**: I killed a lot of High Elves in the Great War, and I didn't die. I guess that makes me a war hero.
[War Is Hell](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WarIsHell): "The 'Great War'...there was nothing great about it. Thousands died on both sides, and where did it get us?"
[Authority in Name Only](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AuthorityInNameOnly): Despite being Jarl, the *real* power in Riften belongs to Maven and, potentially,  (SPOILER) the Dragonborn .

[Crouching Moron, Hidden Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CrouchingMoronHiddenBadass): [Dummied Out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DummiedOut) dialogue indicates Laila would have personally fought in the defense of The Rift, and gives a powerful ["The Reason You Suck" Speech](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheReasonYouSuckSpeech) to Maven about how Maven is [Only in It for the Money](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OnlyInItForTheMoney) and has no honor like the Nords do.

[Dirty Coward](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DirtyCoward):
    - General dialogue between her and her steward reveals that Laila has an emergency carriage at the ready for her to escape should a dragon attack Riften. Of course, given what happened to Helgen, one can argue that her preparations are more between this and just having common sense, especially given how small Riften is compared to other major cities. - Averted in the cut content, as she's perfectly willing to remain in the city during the civil war and face off against a Dragonborn led Imperial assault.
[Distaff Counterpart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DistaffCounterpart): To Igmund. See his entry for elaboration.

[Fantastic Racism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism): Surprisingly averted; she is the only starting Stormcloak-aligned Jarl who doesn't show racism in any way. The fact that she has two Bosmer in her court, one of them being her steward and the other her court wizard, says much.

[Hidden Depths](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HiddenDepths): While it may be easy at first glance to deem Laila an incompetent twit who has no idea what's really happening in Riften, conversations and quests reveal she's more insightful than she seems. If she wasn't such a [Horrible Judge of Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HorribleJudgeOfCharacter) in trusting her corrupt advisors and [Maven](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDon), she would probably be a good Jarl and Riften would be a very different city.
    - If the Imperials win and she's driven into exile, she accepts the blame and admits to having been a bad Jarl who let her people down. This is in contrast to Skald and Korir, who blame everyone *but* themselves. - Idle chatter between her and her advisors reveals that she *does* realize Riften is deeply corrupt and she does want to clean up the city. But because most of her advisors are bought and paid for by the Thieves' Guild and Maven Black-Briar, they reassure her that the problem will be taken care of or isn't as bad as she's heard, and Laila believes them and doesn't press the matter. - While she's a Stormcloak-aligned Jarl, it's only because she believes in Ulfric's cause and sees his claim to the throne as legitimate. Her real interest is the state of her Hold, because she truly wants to be a good ruler for her people and take care of them. If you are her Thane and the Stormcloaks have won the war, she may confide in you that she has a lot of private doubts about Ulfric's character, and fears that his rule over Skyrim may not be the 'golden age' his more fervent followers believe it will be. QUOTE **Laila:** While I feel Ulfric's cause is just, my concern is for the people of The Rift. How can they continue to lead their already meager lives with dark clouds looming overhead? My heart goes out to them. If only our coffers were deeper, I could protect them as if they were my own family.

[Honor-Related Abuse](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HonorRelatedAbuse): Treats her younger son, Saerlund, as mentally ill because he supports the Empire, to the point of ordering her court mage to find a cure. Thankfully, said court mage is an [Absent-Minded Professor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AbsentMindedProfessor) who almost certainly hasn't really gotten started on that; and apart from being emotionally insensitive and placing her son under house arrest more or less, she otherwise treats him fairly well.

[Horrible Judge of Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HorribleJudgeOfCharacter): She has no idea all of her advisers are bought and paid for by Maven and the Thieves' Guild, and that Maven is basically running Riften under her nose.

[Hypocrite](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Hypocrite): Had a woman thrown in jail and her son disinherited and treated for mental sickness both for daring to criticize the Stormcloaks and raising concerns about Ulfric's motives and character, but speak to her after a Stormcloak victory and she'll reveal that she shares those same concerns about Ulfric.
[Irony](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Irony): A woman with the sobriquet "Law-Giver" rules over the setting's [Wretched Hive](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WretchedHive) and is entirely inept at cleaning it up.

[Puppet Queen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PuppetQueen): Those members of her court who aren't ineffectual are working for the Thieves' Guild and [Maven Black-Briar](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IOwnThisTown), to the extent that Maven and the Guild are the *real* ones running Riften. Fittingly, if the Imperials take Riften, they just dispense with the pretense and appoint Maven as Jarl. However, Laila does get a moment of agency in sending the player to round up the Skooma smugglers working in the city, despite her steward saying it's nothing to be worried about.

[Surrounded by Idiots](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SurroundedByIdiots): Invokes this when proclaiming the Dragonborn as Thane of the Rift, claiming that they've done more for Riften in a short time than *any* of her advisors have ever managed. Justified because all of her advisors are either inept or on Maven's payroll.

[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): For all her ineptitude and naïveté, she cares deeply for her hold, has little to none of the [Fantastic Racism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism) usually associated with the Stormcloaks, and recognizes those who help combat Riften's seedier side like Mjoll and the Dragonborn.
[Upper-Class Twit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UpperClassTwit): Laila and her children are probably the most prominent example of this trope in the game.

[Conspiracy Theorist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ConspiracyTheorist): He believes that every Imperial sympathizer is a spy of some kind, and even threatens to execute Brina Merilis and Horik Halfhand just for being ex-Legionnaires note  It must be conceded, though, that wearing their armour as they do is quite a provocation; he makes a point of saying that if he finds *evidence* of them spying for Tullius, *then* he'll have them killed, which is a more or less reasonable stance on this sort of thing in a state of war
    - One step further than that is his belief that the reasons dragons are attacking Skyrim is because of the ban of worshiping Talos, and that they will stop if the Stormcloaks win. Well, he's halfway right on that, since there *is* a divine hand behind their return...

[Fantastic Racism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism): Hates giants, and is always eager to send the Dragonborn to kill them. Justified, since they *are* a very dangerous nuisance to his hold - enough to give *dragons* a run for their money; they can easily kill with *[one hit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneHitKO)*. Granted, they don't usually go out of their way to attack anyone, but it is *very easy* to accidentally piss them off.

[Got Volunteered](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GotVolunteered): Has apparently been "drafting" just about every able-bodied man and woman in the Pale as soldiers to Ulfric's cause, out of a belief that everyone in his hold should share in the glory of a Stormcloak victory. This has left his Hold sparsely populated, with a severe lack of guards to defend it or tradesmen to bolster its economy.

[Hypocrite](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Hypocrite): He insists that all true Nords have a duty to join the Stormcloaks and fight for Skyrim's freedom... and sneers at his servant Bulfrek for wanting to do just that.

[Jerkass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Jerkass):
    - His servant Bulfrek wants to join the Stormcloaks to prove himself a worthy Nord. When he asks Skald for leave to do so, Skald laughs at the idea of a servant wanting to be a warrior. - He also refuses to let his court wizard, Madena, leave the court. Madena is a [Shell-Shocked Veteran](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShellShockedVeteran) of the Great War and desperately wants to essentially take a mental health holiday, and Skald won't allow it.

[Leeroy Jenkins](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LeeroyJenkins):
    - Has this mentality when it comes to allocating troops to the Stormcloak cause, which pretty much leaves Dawnstar undefended. His own housecarl (politely) accuses him of not understanding the magnitude of the Civil War. - You may or may not notice him amid the bedlam that is the Siege of Windhelm; he apparently decides to go down fighting.
[Manchild](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManChild): According to the town alchemist, who's even older than him, he's been a brat his entire life since he took the hold's seat when he was a boy.

[Miles Gloriosus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MilesGloriosus): Insists on sending all of his soldiers to the front, because it would be more glorious. His housecarl protests that this would leave their defenses completely lacking.
[Try Not to Die](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TryNotToDie): If you accept his bounty for a giant, he sends you off with "Bye! Try not to get stomped by a giant!"

[Villainous Valour](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainousValour): One of his few positive points, instead of cowering during the Siege of Windhelm, he elects to go down fighting. Not that he proves very effective.
[You Have to Believe Me!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouHaveToBelieveMe): He often rabbles about how there are Imperial spies in Dawnstar, but no one believes him.

[Authority in Name Only](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AuthorityInNameOnly): He's the ruler of a ruined, barely-inhabited, resource-poor frozen wasteland and no one, not the other Jarls, not the College, not even Winterhold's few remaining non-mage citizens take him seriously. He's pretty bitter about it.
[Badass Longcoat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassLongcoat): Same as Ulfric's, but in a different colour.

[Determinator](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Determinator): Even so, he's grimly resigned and dedicated to protecting what remains of his hold to the best of his ability.
QUOTE **Korir:** I don't care how many colleges they build! Or how much the sea swallows up! I'll outlast them all!

[Does Not Like Magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DoesNotLikeMagic): He's convinced the College blew up Winterhold, something the mages deny strenuously. Given that an entire city collapsing doesn't happen on a whim, and the traditional Nordic distrust for magic that isn't purely beneficial, he's steadfast in his assumptions.

[Dude, Where's My Respect?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DudeWheresMyRespect):
    - The destruction of most of his city has really damaged his Hold's reputation in Skyrim, and he's outraged that he commands so little respect and authority among the other Jarls because of this. - In the quest to become Thane of Winterhold, he sends the Dragonborn to retrieve the lost Helm of Winterhold, the crown worn by a former prospective High King who would have ruled with Winterhold as his seat of power. Korir wants it to remind the other Holds of their historical importance and the fact that they once rivaled Windhelm and Solitude in terms of power.

[Fantastic Racism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism): Has it in for elves pretty bad. He encourages this in his son as well, though he has a hatred of mages that is far more fantastical and prominent.

[Feeling Oppressed by Their Existence](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FeelingOppressedByTheirExistence): A conversation between Dagur, the innkeeper, and his wife Haran indicates that Korir complains about some of the inn's customers (mages visiting the College, who are often also elves), and that his complaints "suggest" this.
QUOTE **Dagur:** I understand Korir has been complaining about our customers again.<br data-format="\\"/>**Haran:** What of it? It's our inn, and they cause him no harm.<br data-format="\\"/>**Dagur:** I believe he was suggesting their presence causes him harm.<br data-format="\\"/>**Haran:** Well, then he's welcome to eat and drink at home, isn't he?
[Happily Married](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HappilyMarried): To his wife Thaena, who is also his housecarl.

[Jerkass Has a Point](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkassHasAPoint): If he's still Jarl during the College of Winterhold questline when  (SPOILER) Ancano tries to harness the Eye of Magnus, causing magical disturbances to be felt throughout the city which could spread devastation across the entire world if not stopped , he reasserts his belief that the College was somehow responsible for the earlier disaster. It's hard to blame him.

[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): He's very devoted to his hold, which is really saying something considering Winterhold is a dilapidated backwater by the time of the game. He apparently has been tireless in trying to restore the city's prestige and is outraged that his city does not get the respect he feels it deserves.

[The Resenter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheResenter): To mages in general and the College in particular. He's particularly bitter that the object of his hatred is pretty much the only reason why Winterhold is even still on the map anymore.

[Spear Counterpart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpearCounterpart): To Jarl Idgrod. Both have difficulties that hurt their reputation (Idgrod's visions, Korir's collapsed city), but are still among the most reasonable and respectable Jarls in their respective factions.
[Benevolent Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BenevolentBoss): To Brill and later to Whiterun as a whole upon becoming Jarl.<!--* BraidsOfBarbarism: Nord.-->

[Cool Old Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolOldGuy): Looks to be in his late sixties. For 30 years he was a commander in the Imperial Legions, and that was apparently *after* he had already made a name for himself as one of the most badass Companions ever, so yeah. And he still participates in the Siege of Whiterun, sword in hand.
[Cool Sword](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolSword): Made of Skyforge Steel, courtesy of his brother [Eorlund Gray-Mane](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UltimateBlacksmith).
[Pet the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PetTheDog): After Brill became a depressed alcoholic, Vignar got him clean and gave him a job.
[Rank Scales with Asskicking](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RankScalesWithAsskicking): Out of all the Jarls, aside from Ulfric, he likely has the most battle experience.

[Real Men Love Jesus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RealMenLoveJesus): He's a devout Talos worshipper.
QUOTE "If this were my Empire, I'd be able to worship whomever I damn well pleased! You wish to see an Empire without Talos?! Without its soul?!"

[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): His main concern as Jarl is to make sure the transition of power goes as smoothly as possible so as to prevent any disruption in the lives of his people. He is also very receptive to the threat of dragons and makes it his top priority to defend against them by increasing the number of guards and is very meticulous about maintaining steady supplies of food and water.

[Retired Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RetiredBadass): Of the Companions, mainly, and he still lives in Jorrvaskr at least part of the time. He also mentions that he, in a similar vein to Ulfric, was a Legion Commander for thirty years.
[Shut Up, Hannibal!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShutUpHannibal): He gives one to Balgruuf when he tries to chew him out for supporting Ulfric.

[We Used to Be Friends](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeUsedToBeFriends): His entire clan used to be friends with the Battle-Born, but became enemies after taking opposite sides of the war. Being descendants of Ysgramor's Companions, they may even be distant relatives.

[What the Hell, Hero?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatTheHellHero): There's unused dialogue between him and Balgruuf (seen above in the latter's entry) in which the pair argue over the worship of Talos and the Jarl's accountability to his people. He also lets him have it during the Stormcloak Battle of Whiterun, seeming to be chiding Balgruuf for staying inside Dragonsreach instead of fighting on the front-line with his men.
QUOTE "Skyrim needs a High King who will fight for her! And Whiterun needs a Jarl who will do the same!"

[Benevolent Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BenevolentBoss): The local blacksmith seems to think so. But Dengeir still thinks he has something to do with the Imperial plot that put Siddgeir in power and will ask you to break into his house. The quest makes it unclear whether or not his suspicions are true.

[Better the Devil You Know](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BetterTheDevilYouKnow): This is why he supports Ulfric; he's the only Stormcloak Jarl who will openly say he considers Ulfric a self-centered, power-hungry egomaniac whom he doesn't trust as far as he can throw. Still, he'd rather deal with him, someone from whom he knows what to expect, and who is at least close enough to the action to know how to effectively run Skyrim, than an Emperor and a council seated a thousand miles away making decisions about a land of which they know virtually nothing.

[Conspiracy Theorist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ConspiracyTheorist): Thinks that there are Imperial spies all around him. Even his own brother (with whom he lives) is kinda fed up with it.  (SPOILER) Unlike with Skald, however, some of his paranoia [appears to have some merit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ProperlyParanoid) when you do some of his side quests. Somewhat.

tropeName: Jerk with a Heart of Gold
tropeNotes: [Jerk with a Heart of Gold](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkWithAHeartOfGold): Dengeir's a grumpy fellow and his paranoia causes him to distrust people he really shouldn't worry about but unlike Siddgeir, he's mostly a benevolent ruler as Jarl.

[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): At least more reasonable than his nephew Siddgeir. He's the only replacement Jarl to ask you to perform a task before naming you Thane. However, he's asking you to do it because bandits are attacking innocents, compared to his nephew's selfish reasons.
QUOTE "Well, for one thing, I won't drain the town treasury buying myself fancy clothes and expensive mead! Nor will I get involved with criminals trying to take advantage of honest folk! I may be an old man, but I haven't forgotten that a Jarl's first duty is to look after his people."
[Reluctant Retiree](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReluctantRetiree): Regains his position if the Stormcloaks take Falkreath.

[Staking the Loved One](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StakingTheLovedOne): He can give a quest to find his ancestor, a *Volkihar vampire* who was recently released from his tomb by an unwitting grave robber. "Loved one" is a stretch, since the vampire was entombed for centuries and Dengeir never knew him, but he's still a member of the Falkreath royal family and Dengeir desperately needs him killed for the safety of the hold.

[Armchair Military](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArmchairMilitary): Demands that his steward boil down his detailed field report on the Stormcloaks' military progress to "Are we winning or not?", and orders the discussion tabled when he can't get a direct answer.
[Asskicking Leads to Leadership](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AsskickingLeadsToLeadership): Presumably, he was chosen as replacement Jarl due to the Stormcloaks' insistence on this.
[Bald of Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BaldOfEvil): An appropriately barren head for the head of a clan of robber-barons.

[Blatant Lies](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlatantLies): Like Igmund, if asked as Jarl he will categorically deny that the marketplace attack had anything to do with the Forsworn. Unlike Igmund, he has a [very good reason](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NebulousCriminalConspiracy) for being involved in the coverup, besides simply trying to keep the peace...

[Dude, Where's My Respect?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DudeWheresMyRespect): As the head of Markarth's richest and most influential family, you'd think that he'd have the Jarl eating out of his palm, like Maven has with Laila. Yet for all his wealth Thongvor can't even get Jarl Igmund to give him the time of day, to his considerable frustration.
QUOTE **Thongvor:** Jarl can refuse to see me all he likes. He can't ignore us forever!

[Due to the Dead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DueToTheDead): His first appearance is him angrily asking the local priest of Arkay why people aren't being allowed into the Hall of the Dead and voicing his suspicion that the bodies of his ancestors are somehow being desecrated. It's a possibility that he (understandably) does not like at all.

[Fantastic Racism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism): Plays the stereotype of the angry, xenophobic Stormcloak completely straight. Even glossing over his family's exploitation and abuse of the Reachmen, he also shares many Stormcloak supporters' prejudices against elves, and spares no insults to an elven Dragonborn about how "[their] kind" ruined the Empire. He also has problems discerning the difference between Imperials the race and Imperials the institution in his ranting at Brother Verulus when you first see him.

[Feudal Overlord](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FeudalOverlord): Essentially becomes this should the Stormcloaks put him in charge, with him and his lackeys "bleeding the Reach dry" with taxes to funnel towards Ulfric's rebellion and talk of further enslaving the Reachmen into his mines.

[General Ripper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GeneralRipper): Probably even worse than his predecessor about this. Like Igmund, he hates the Forsworn and plans to put together another militia to hunt them down and enslave or "cleanse" them from the Reach, and enthusiastically demands that everyone capable with a bow be sent out to hunt *the dragons* as well.

[I Own This Town](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IOwnThisTown): His family's mine pretty much makes the income for the city, and the miners consist of captured Forsworn and convicted criminals. When he becomes Jarl, this trope becomes literally true. He will also complain that the Jarl doesn't listen to him enough despite his family's huge affluence and influence.

[Justice by Other Legal Means](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JusticeByOtherLegalMeans): While it's impossible to publicly expose his family's dealings with  (SPOILER) the Forsworn , by  (SPOILER) completing "Season Unending" and yielding Markarth to the Stormcloaks, then reclaiming the Reach for the Imperial Legion , an Empire-aligned Dragonborn can still rid Markarth of the Thongvor and his cronies by having them exiled to Windhelm as Stormcloak traitors.

[Karma Houdini](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KarmaHoudini): While Thongvor is implied to be in the dark on his brother's corrupt business dealings, that doesn't stop him from exploiting the benefits for political gain. And, like fellow replacement Jarl Maven Black-Briar, he can't be taken down a peg and remains [essential](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameplayAllyImmortality) and untouchable to the player. [However](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SubvertedTrope), by siding with the Empire and [taking the right steps](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuideDangIt), he can be exiled from Markarth instead.

[Properly Paranoid](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ProperlyParanoid): He's suspicious that people aren't allowed into the Hall of the Dead, speculating that the bodies of his ancestors are being defiled. He's  (SPOILER) not wrong, as you discover if you persuade the priest of Arkay to tell you why the Hall of the Dead is closed; it turns out there's a cannibal in there having lunch. Whether Thongvor's relatives are among those that have recently been chewed on isn't stated, but it's certainly possible.

[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): He's receptive to the threat of dragons and tries to have parties made to hunt them. This doesn't fly, though, as his steward reminds him it would be ineffective seeing as how his men don't have the training to take on dragons (hell, the guys at Whiterun were only able to beat one because they had the Dragonborn on their side). He is also very respectful to a Stormcloak Dragonborn, and if you perform Thonar's "service," though he doesn't know the exact details of it, he will genuinely thank you.
    - If the Dragonborn isn't Thane beforehand, he'll allow the player to become Thane if the Stormcloaks take Markarth, provided they purchase property and help the citizens of the Reach, even if the player happens to be an Imperial or an Elf note  in fact, it's actually *easier* to become Thane of the Reach if Thongvar is Jarl, since he allows you to immediately purchase property and then only requires you to help 5 citizens of Markarth; Igmund not only requires you to deal with some Forsworn, but also to retrieve a unique shield before he'll let you buy property and help the citizens of Markarth .

[Retired Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RetiredBadass): Like Ulfric and many Stormcloaks, he's a former Legionnaire, and still has fond memories of his service (at least, from back when "the Empire stood up for Skyrim" anyway).
[Spear Counterpart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpearCounterpart): To Maven Black-Briar. See her entry for elaboration.

tropeName: I Fight for the Strongest Side!
tropeNotes: [I Fight for the Strongest Side!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IFightForTheStrongestSide): Even though Sorli is the Stormcloaks' Jarl in Morthal, she doesn't really express any strong sentiments for them or their ideals, or seem to have any real grievance with the Empire (indeed, her mine sells iron to the Imperials and she swears by the Eight, implying stronger Imperial ties). It's implied that Sorli is only aligned with the Stormcloaks because they're letting her be in charge, and that Ulfric is only going with her because, frankly, there aren't really any better options out in Hjaalmarch.

[It's All About Me](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItsAllAboutMe): Unlike most Jarls, who are primarily loyal to their hold, Sorli only sees Hjaalmarch as a springboard for her own reputation, and openly plans on packing up and moving to Riften once she's gotten bored of running things in Morthal. Local cynic Jorgen even states that they've only swapped out a Jarl "lost in her own head" for one that cares for nothing but herself.

[Oh, My Gods!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OhMyGods):
    - "By Ysgramor's axe!" All the more amusing if you have the rebuilt weapon equipped at the time. - In a very interesting and telling exclamation, doing "Laid to Rest" with her will have her blurt out "By the Eight!" instead "By the Nine!", implying that either habit or lack of conviction has prevented her from counting Talos.

[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): If you haven't completed Morthal's special questline, she has the same intelligent response as her Imperial counterpart: to accept your word on the matter and provide you with a mob of ([somewhat problematic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AnnoyingVideoGameHelper)) supporters.
[Token Minority](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TokenMinority): Her housecarl is the only non-human replacement the Stormcloaks have.

[Appeal to Tradition](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AppealToTradition): Another common defence by Empire-sympathetic characters, who argue that as Talos was the founder of the Empire, he would much rather see it endure rather than crumble, even if he isn't worshipped within it anymore. Again, there are significant counter-arguments <sup>note </sup>  Rewind back to *[The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/TheElderScrollsIIIMorrowind)*, where you meet an avatar of Talos near the end of the game, an old Imperial soldier named Wulf (perhaps referring to Wulfharth, one of his constituent personalities) who more or less tells you that the Empire has had its time and it wouldn't be so bad if "something new" takes its place, so it can be inferred that he is at best indifferent to its fate .

[Assimilation Plot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AssimilationPlot): The Stormcloaks and Empire dissidents believe the Empire of Tamriel is removing their freedom to worship Talos, removing their traditions, and taking away their cultural identity to be part of the Empire's growing mass. Something which they believe is [under the Aldmeri Dominion's heel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ANaziByAnyOtherName), a faction they were previously at war with and the same group that sent the Thalmor to skyrim.

[Awakening the Sleeping Giant](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AwakeningTheSleepingGiant): Their off-hand decision to execute some poor schmuck crossing the border at the wrong time just because they were on a tight schedule will lead directly to their defeat by the Stormcloaks and loss of Imperial control of Skyrim, should the Dragonborn feel compelled to join the rebellion. In your first meetings with Balgruuf and Ulfric, you can explicitly cite the execution attempt as the source of your ire.

[Badass Army](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassArmy): *Much* weaker than during the reign of the Septims, but the Imperial Legion was still strong enough to wipe out the Dominion forces in Cyrodiil. It's generally accepted that the Empire, as a whole, is much stronger than the Stormcloaks (they still control half of Skyrim, and all of Cyrodiil and High Rock, after all), and could defeat them in a matter of months if they actually ever decided to seriously bring the hammer down upon them; however, the Empire is unwilling to commit any more legions to Skyrim, as doing so would require weakening their border with the Thalmor — a tactical blunder on which they're afraid the Dominion would only too happily capitalize.

[Badass Creed](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassCreed): Just like the Stormcloaks, they have one. The Dragonborn has to take it if they want to join the Legion.
QUOTE **Imperial Oath**: "Upon my honor I do swear undying loyalty to the Emperor, Titus Mede II,  <sup>*</sup>  Or simply "The Emperor" if  (SPOILER) Mede has already been killed in the Dark Brotherhood questline   and unwavering obedience to the officers of his great Empire. May those above judge me, and those below take me, if I fail in my duty. Long live the Emperor! Long live the Empire!"
[Can't Argue with Elves](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CantArgueWithElves): The White-Gold Concordat essentially yoked them with this.

[Cultural Posturing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CulturalPosturing): Some of them, including Tullius, like to point out how glorious the cosmopolitan empire is compared to Skyrim. Tullius is also initially of the opinion that *all* the Imperial provinces, not only Skyrim (but especially Skyrim), would instantly degenerate into barbarism and anarchy without the guiding hand of Legions to enforce order, which is just a dickish thing to say no matter how you slice it. <sup>note </sup>  However, looking into both the past and present, there is a degree of truth to some of this. While "barbarism" is a disrespectful misconception of cultures just as advanced as the Empire, several provinces have been shown to beat up on each other and fight internally whenever an Empire has been absent, such as the Great House wars in Morrowind, the Crown-Forbear conflicts in Hammerfell, and the repeated sackings of Orsinium. And let's not forget the long, chaotic, bloody interregnum that raged on for over 400 years before the Empire was rebuilt, destabilizing much of Tamriel. Furthermore, many of the Jarls, regardless of alignment, have been shown to be either corrupt or incompetent, further worsening Skyrim's situation. 
QUOTE **Imperial Legates:** Of course, the Nord Kings — oh, I'm sorry, *Jarls* can't really control their own people.

[The Empire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheEmpire): While not "evil" by any means (see [Grey-and-Gray Morality](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GreyAndGrayMorality)), their presence in Skyrim as a large, faceless Empire led by bureaucrats in a far-off land is a source of tension to many of the people — including, of course, the Stormcloaks.

[Fantastic Racism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism): Zig-zagged. On the one hand, they're adamant about the superiority of the Empire and Imperial way of life, though this is more of a culture and code than actually the based on Cyrodilic people or province. Tullius in particular has absolutely no respect for Nordic tradition, dismissing them as crude, backwards barbarians even to his own Nord legate's face. On the other hand, they *don't* have the Stormcloaks' general distrust and dislike for mer and beastfolk, with an altmer called Fasendil commanding the Imperial forces in the Rift, and don't question your motivation for enlisting based on race.
[Hero Antagonist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroAntagonist): Within the Dark Brotherhood storyline.

tropeName: I'll Pretend I Didn't Hear That
tropeNotes: [I'll Pretend I Didn't Hear That](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IllPretendIDidntHearThat): After the White-Gold Concordat was signed, the Empire turned a blind eye to Talos worship, rather than actively silencing it. When [Ulfric made a big deal about Talos worship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceJobBreakingItHero), he attracted the Thalmor to Skyrim, forcing the Empire to tighten its grip to preserve the truce. Still, a few Empire-affiliated Jarls retain this policy.

[Jerkass Has a Point](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkassHasAPoint): Imperial-aligned Nords do like to point out that while the Stormcloaks might have some points regarding the Empire's recent conduct, Skyrim has still been part of the Empire since pretty much the beginning; Skyrim was among the most enthusiastic supporters of Tiber Septim and his burgeoning Third Empire and according to most sources pledged vassalage to him almost as soon as he became Emperor, and that trying to get out the moment things become tough is being complete fair-weather friends, ignoring the 600 years of very peaceful and prosperous good the Empire did for Skyrim.

[Les Collaborateurs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LesCollaborateurs): Ulfric partly justifies his rebellion by claiming that the entire Empire has become this to the Aldmeri Dominion. While that's certainly a bit hyperbolic, the accusation does ring somewhat true, as there are quite a few prominent Empire-affiliated nobles at the Thalmor Embassy party <sup>note </sup>  Jarl Siddgeir, Thane Erikur, Maven Black-Briar and Vittoria Vici  who are downright chummy with the Thalmor, or are at least quick to bury the hatchet with them for the sake of commerce and their own self-interest. General Tullius, also begrudgingly attending the party, is fully aware of this and disgusted by it.
QUOTE **Tullius:** Look around the room and you'll see what we're up against. Just between you and me, [a lot of what Ulfric says about the Empire is true](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkassHasAPoint).

[Necessarily Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NecessarilyEvil): The Empire genuinely believes that peace is the best way to deal with the Aldmeri Dominion and sacrifices must be made for the greater good. However, Skyrim and Hammerfell are examples of The Empire forcing others to make sacrifices. Skyrim had to sacrifice its traditions and beliefs while Hammerfell was abandoned by The Empire.

[Order Versus Chaos](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OrderVersusChaos): A possible way to view the conflict between the Empire and Stormcloaks, respectively. Legates and pro-Imperials tend to lean towards this view in particular when it comes to war and the Stormcloaks, with The Empire representing Order and the Stormcloaks representing Chaos.

[Praetorian Guard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PraetorianGuard): Since the Blades are sworn to follow one of the Dragon Blood (which the Mede dynasty cannot claim), the Empire resorted to making a new organization devoted to the protection of the Emperor. The Penitus Oculatus exists for this reason.

[Pragmatic Villainy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PragmaticVillainy): [Downplayed](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Downplayed), due to the [nature](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GrayAndGreyMorality) of the war and how most Jarl's reasonings aren't very "evil". The jarls have partnered up with the empire because they find it more practical than joining the Stormcloaks:
    - Jarl Balgruuf the Greater joined because Whiterun needs the money that's brought in by trading with The Empire. Whiterun is an economic hub of Skyrim with numerous merchants operating out of the town, and many traders come through the hold on their travels, so it's in the best interests of his people to keep the Empire around and keep the coin flowing. - Jarl Elisif the Fair has a personal reason to go against the Stormcloaks, Ulfric killed her husband Torygg as a show of power and to kickstart the war. - Jarl Idgrod Ravencrone is disinterested in the civil war and she joined the Empire despite her hatred for the Thalmor. - Jarl Siddgeir was put in power because his uncle supported the Stormcloaks and Siddgeir fully supports the Thalmor. - Jarl Igmund only supports the Empire because he believes that it protects his hold from the Thalmor. - Brina Merilis supports the Empire because she served them during the war and knows they want peace at all costs. - Maven Black-Briar supports the Empire because of her lust for power. It also wouldn't be surprising if she joined the Empire for economic reasons. - Kraldar supports the Empire because he wants to restore Winterhold to its former glory. - Brunwulf Free-Winter supports the Empire because he's against Ulfric's chauvinist views.

[Punch-Clock Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PunchClockVillain): For a Stormcloak-aligned character, they're this because they don't entirely agree with persecuting Talos worshipers, but they'd rather not get on the Thalmor's bad side at this point either.

[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): Far less so than its previous incarnations, admittedly, but back in *Morrowind* and *Oblivion,* they were dragging a culture that still had outright slavery kicking and screaming into modernity. Additionally, you were viewing them in their own homeland, so of course they would look good by comparison. Here, however, they're involved with suppressing religious freedom (albeit potentially under protest), and they do knowingly sponsor two corrupt rulers and engage in blackmail; and their soldiers do engage in what can only be described as war crimes, as in the case of Angi's family.

[Romanticism Versus Enlightenment](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RomanticismVersusEnlightenment): The Enlightenment side of the conflict. The Imperial Legion is the occupying military force of a well-intentioned and cosmopolitan nation, with a leader who acts mostly as a [Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure) but occasionally shows the side of a sneering imperialist who [believes that the locals would descend into anarchy and barbarism if not for the laws and guidance his empire provides](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhiteMansBurden).

[Shoot the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShootTheDog): Giving "large sections" of Hammerfell to the Dominion, as well as banning Talos worship, in order to stop the Great War. Needless to say, the Redguards were not pleased about essentially being sacrificed to the Thalmor, and they were able to drive out the Dominion themselves (this is used, both in-universe and by fans, as an example of why the Empire was wrong to surrender). The Nords were likewise not happy about one of their most popular gods being banned, and this is one of the prime motivations for the Stormcloak rebellion.
    - It is worth noting however, that Imperial Legionnaires did actually stay behind voluntarily to help the Redguards stand against the Dominion, though whether that could be considered an intentional act on the part of Imperial *leadership* itself, rather than just the decision of those Legionnaires in particular, is debatable. - it's also pointed out that the Thalmor more or less ignored Skyrim until Ulfric started screaming about Talos and murdering people. The Thalmor then moved in to fan the flames when they smelled Nord weakness and the Empire had to crack down to at least pretend they were trying to stop Talos worship. It explains why Tellius is so dismissive of Nord tradition as he is the ultimate pragmatic.

[The Smurfette Principle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSmurfettePrinciple): While probably unintentional, in this game you'll see a lot fewer females in the Legion than you will in the Stormcloaks. On the other hand, all female Legionnaires in Skyrim are in positions of high rank.

[Vestigial Empire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VestigialEmpire): Currently only controls Cyrodiil, Skyrim, High Rock, and parts of Morrowind. To make matters worse, much of Skyrim is rebelling against their rule. And since Skyrim bridges all of these regions together, if the Stormcloaks win the civil war, the Empire could be fatally fractured. But wait, it gets better; conversation between Ulfric and Galmar implies that High Rock is barely involved in Imperial affairs and is only tangentially allied with the Empire. They tried to use this fact in order to ally with High Rock themselves, but failed in doing so. On the other hand, if the Empire wins the civil war, the Blades are reformed,  (SPOILER) the Dark Brotherhood is destroyed , and one of its increasingly prominent citizens is of the [Dragon Blood](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DivineParentage) once again, the Empire might actually start to pull itself out of this rut, as this is the most stable it has been in *centuries.*

[Well-Intentioned Extremist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WellIntentionedExtremist): Sure, they may do some questionable things in-game and in the past (the signing of the White-Gold Concordat and the secession of Hammerfell being two of the biggest examples, and then there's Angi's story of two drunk Imperial soldiers murdering her family), but most if not all of the pro-Imperials that we see in game generally do believe that the Empire is the only way that Tamriel can present a unified front against the Dominion.

[What the Hell, Hero?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatTheHellHero): They got this reaction after the signing of the White-Gold Concordat, and again after the secession of Hammerfell. They tend to have the attitude that both actions were justified, however.

[Anti-Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiHero): On the Empire side, he generally fulfills the role of [Big Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigGood) for you, but he's rather... [gruff](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GrumpyOldMan).

[Anti-Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiVillain): To the Stormcloak side. He's just a man doing his job, serving his Emperor to the best of his ability and trying his hardest to preserve the Empire that he loves.
[Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad): Should you side with the Stormcloaks, he is this for the Civil War storyline, as defeating him and his Legion is required to end the war.
[Big Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigGood): Should you side with the Empire, he's the primary authority figure directing you throughout the war.

[Crazy Cultural Comparison](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CrazyCulturalComparison): If he gets the Dragonborn's help in fighting the Stormcloaks, by the time he gets Windhelm he needs to pause a moment while sentencing Ulfric to death to note he'll send him "to... to wherever you people go when you die", to which Rikke needs to answer for him. Needless to say, Ulfric probably holds a grim smile through it all.

[Cultural Posturing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CulturalPosturing): He initially holds a somewhat dim view of Nord traditions and culture in comparison to the "more civilized" Imperials' and tends to be utterly baffled by the Nords' tendency to put [Honor Before Reason](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HonorBeforeReason), but by the end of the Imperial campaign he admits to having grown found of Skyrim and its culture, thinking about enjoying his retirement there instead of his native Cyrodiil. QUOTE **Tullius:** The Legion's always been here. Without us to keep order, the provinces would fall into barbarism and lawlessness. [Especially Skyrim](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EspeciallyZoidberg).
    - Notably, he also understands that he needs to have some insight into Nord culture if he is to be able to effectively engage the Stormcloaks, and has Rikke brief him on Skyrim's culture and history when needed.

[Despair Event Horizon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DespairEventHorizon): At the end of the Stormcloak questline.  (SPOILER) By the time you reach him during the Battle of Solitude, he's essentially given up. Rikke even says as much, though he'll still get up and fight you alongside her. Before he's executed, he even tells Ulfric that his rebellion has given the Thalmor exactly what they want.

[Everyone Has Standards](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EveryoneHasStandards): Even despite his dismissive obtuseness towards Nordic culture, he still recognizes the sacred nature of the Thu'um, and considers Ulfric to have profaned it by using it in his act of kingslaying.
QUOTE **Tullius:** Some here in Helgen call you a hero. But a hero doesn't use a power like the Voice to murder his king and usurp his throne.

[Four-Star Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FourStarBadass): He's a 'troubleshooter' for the Emperor; basically, he's sent where existing commands are faltering against concerted opposition (like Skyrim's situation). Should the Empire prevail all the way to Windhelm, he's out in the front, leading the charge. He even has the guts to face Ulfric in person, knowing full well of his Thu'um and how he tends to curb-stomp most people.
[Front Line General](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FrontLineGeneral): During the Battle for Windhelm he fights on the frontlines despite being a commander.

[Going Native](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoingNative): Downplayed, but if the player sides with the Legion, Tullius mentions he's probably not going back to Cyrodil, noting that while he's never going to really understand [the Nords](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HornyVikings), [or get used to the damn cold](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GrimUpNorth), he's come to see Skyrim as his home and respect the fact that the [harshness inherent to the country tends to make people improve themselves](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MiseryBuildsCharacter).

[Grumpy Old Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GrumpyOldMan): He's ages and you get the feeling that he'd rather get this war over with to prepare for greater threats like the inevitable second war with the Thalmor.

[Hidden Depths](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HiddenDepths): Although he loathes Ulfric and sees his rebellion as short-sighted treason, if you've distinguished yourself as a Legionnaire before "Diplomatic Immunity", he'll confide in you a bit during the party that he understands and even agrees with a lot of Ulfric's criticisms of the Empire's current state, showing that he can still empathize with where the Stormcloaks are coming from even if he disagrees with them.<!--zce* HypercompetentSidekick: To Jarl Elisif.-->

tropeName: I'll Pretend I Didn't Hear That
tropeNotes:
[I'll Pretend I Didn't Hear That](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IllPretendIDidntHearThat):
    - Has this personal policy towards any accidental offhand profession of Talos worship amongst his troops. QUOTE **Rikke:** Talos be with you [Ulfric]...
    **Tullius:** What was that, Legate?
    **Rikke:** Nothing... just saying goodbye.
    **Tullius** ...Right. - He invokes this on the player when spoken to after the war. He tells the player that with Ulfric dead, he thinks most of the Stormcloaks will accept that the war is over and return home, save for the most diehard believers, and Skyrim will be peaceful again. He admits that he's not so sure about the truce with the Thalmor lasting, but tells the player to keep it between them and him.

[Jerkass Has a Point](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkassHasAPoint): For all of his [Cultural Posturing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CulturalPosturing), a brief look at Tamriel's history shows that he's absolutely right about the provinces falling to barbarism and anarchy without the Imperial Legion. The periods between each Empire have been times of chaos and strife, especially the Interregnum after the Second Empire fell, in which [nearly all of Nirn was consumed by Molag Bal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Videogame/TheElderScrollsOnline) while everyone else was fighting one another.

tropeName: Jerk with a Heart of Gold
tropeNotes:
[Jerk with a Heart of Gold](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkWithAHeartOfGold):
    - If you think the Empire is necessary for Skyrim's protection and prosperity. He's also generally good to his men, and even doubles their pay if the Empire wins the war. After the Imperial campaign, he says that while he may never understand Nords, he's come to respect them. In addition to this, when Alduin attacks Helgen, the first thing Tullius says is "Guards, get the townspeople to safety!" even though he could quite easily have ordered his men to pursue the escaping Ulfric instead. - If the Dragonborn, still bound and helpless (and by all rights still a criminal) runs up to Tullius during the attack on Helgen, he'll simply bark out an almost stupefied "*Run,* you idiot!" In the wake of a dragon attack, even a criminal gets Tullius' benefit of the doubt. Sort of.
[Last-Name Basis](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LastNameBasis): His first name is never revealed anywhere.
[Old Soldier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OldSoldier): He looks to be getting on in years, but that doesn't hamper his ability to lead an army or fight on the front lines.

[Pet the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PetTheDog): During "Missing in Action", you can go to Solitude and ask him to order the Thalmor to free Thorald Gray-Mane... and [he'll always refuse](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SubvertedTrope). The subversion is not intentional, however, as it was supposed to be possible to get him to help, but the Imperial Order letter you were supposed to get from him was left unfinished and the conditions required to get it were made impossible to fulfill. He does have a voiced response to agreeing to your request, bemoaning the "headaches [it] is going to cause", so it's possible to restore the [Pet the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PetTheDog) moment via mods.

[Pragmatic Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PragmaticHero): He really doesn't *get* the Nords' [Honor Before Reason](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HonorBeforeReason) way of life, but he's shown to be a tough, competent, and reasonable man who has been making huge strides in the reunification of Skyrim.

[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): He may be a culturally insensitive boor, but he's loyal to his Empire and does his duty without qualm (well, the occasional general complaint is there); should you win the Civil War by his side, he vows to increase the pay of his soldiers to honor their service, and later reveals in subtle terms that he resents the Thalmor as much as any true Nord would. During the negotiation in "Season Unending", he generally acts a bit more collected and less aggressive than Ulfric.<!--zce* RedOniBlueOni: The blue to Rikke's red.-->

[Say My Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SayMyName):  (SPOILER) When he, you, and Rikke make the final confrontation with Ulfric, Tullius shouts out Ulfric's full name (but not titles) before listing off his crimes.

[The Strategist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheStrategist): He masterminded Ulfric Stormcloak's capture, and had [a dragon not attacked Helgen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpannerInTheWorks), he likely would have succeeded in dealing a great blow to the Stormcloaks. Hadvar notes that, since taking command, Tullius managed to turn the situation in Skyrim around, from a complete rout for the Empire to a near victory...  (SPOILER) before Alduin [interrupts](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpannerInTheWorks) Ulfric's execution.  He is considered by the top brass of the Legion to be a proficient "troubleshooter"; he was sent by the Emperor himself to turn things around in Skyrim.

[Underestimating Badassery](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnderestimatingBadassery): He doesn't expect much tactical brilliance, organization, charisma, or political savvy from the Stormcloaks and their supporters. He's *dangerously* wrong.

[With Us or Against Us](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WithUsOrAgainstUs): Not to the extent of Ulfric and the Stormcloaks, but while he does admit that it's imperative that Whiterun is in Imperial control, he isn't afraid off-hand to consider the notion that if Balgruuf continues to stand outside Imperial influence, the Stormcloaks can pillage his city as far as he's concerned. However, this *has* been after numerous attempts to impress upon Balgruuf that Stormcloaks are moving about his borders, so he's a bit exasperated with Balgruuf's obstinacy. That said, Tullius does end up sending men to aid Balgruuf after he is convinced of an imminent attack on Whiterun.
QUOTE **Tullius:** Well, if he wants to stand outside the protection of the Empire, fine. Let Ulfric pillage his city.<br data-format="\\"/>**Rikke:** [General...](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatTheHellHero)<br data-format="\\"/>**Tullius:** You people and your damn Jarls.

[What Happened to the Mouse?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatHappenedToTheMouse): Granted, you *do*  (SPOILER) kill him at the end of the Stormcloak Civil War quest , but unlike Rikke, Ulfric, and Galmar,  (SPOILER) he cannot be met again in Sovngarde on account of not being a Nord .

[Action Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ActionGirl): As is common for a Nord woman. Her mother was also an [Action Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ActionGirl); as noted below, both her parents were Legionnaires.

[Colonel Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ColonelBadass): The structure of Legion ranks puts "Legate" in a position closely akin to "Colonel", which is the highest rank of line officers in modern militaries. Ironically, in the actual Roman Empire, legates (*legatus*) were in fact comparable to generals and were of the senatorial class.
[Cool Helmet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolHelmet): For some reason, she discards it when  (SPOILER) you and the Stormcloaks corner her and Tullius in Castle Dour. .

[Deadpan Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker): If an Imperial-allied player decides to hold the Greybeards' peace talks, Rikke will let slip some very snide comments whenever Ulfric or Elenwen start talking.

[Distaff Counterpart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DistaffCounterpart): To Galmar Stone-Fist. Both rank very high in their respective factions and are at the front lines throughout their quests. But that's where the similarities end. Unlike Galmar, who relishes every opportunity to savage the Legion that he and Ulfric once served, Rikke is able to empathize with the plight of the Stormcloaks, even though she believes their methods are wrong.

[Heroic BSoD](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicBSOD):  (SPOILER) If you send her screaming to Sovngarde before completing the main quest, she can be found lamenting how she and the Legion wanted to protect Skyrim, but all their war did was kill men and women from both sides, and now she must watch as their souls are devoured by the World Eater, Alduin.

[Hidden Depths](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HiddenDepths): If you talk to her in High Hrothgar before sitting down for the negotiation in "Season Unending", she'll remark that she's always wanted to visit the monastery.
[Last Stand](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LastStand): At the end of the Stormcloak campaign, Ulfric and Galmar offer her the chance to stand down out of respect for their past together. She refuses.
[Military Brat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MilitaryBrat): Both her parents were in the Imperial Legion, and part of the reason she joined was to honor them.
[No True Scotsman](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoTrueScotsman): She basically uses it in the same way as the Stormcloaks do, but with 'Ulfric' replaced with 'the Empire'.
[Number Two](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NumberTwo): To Tullius.

[Patriotic Fervor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PatrioticFervor): Unlike Tullius, who's mainly in Skyrim because it's his duty, Rikke is openly proud of being both a daughter of Skyrim and a legate in the Legion. She sees nothing contradictory in being both. As noted above, both of her parents were Legionnaires and also children of Skyrim, so it's [In the Blood](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InTheBlood).

[Real Men Love Jesus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RealMenLoveJesus): When asked about her opinion on her faith, she curtly cuts you off, saying it's not up for discussion.  (SPOILER) After the deed is done on Ulfric, however, she gives him the parting words "Talos be with you."
[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): Primarily due to being less intransigently contemptuous of Nordic culture than her boss.
[Red Oni, Blue Oni](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedOniBlueOni): The red to Tullius' blue.
[Rousing Speech](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RousingSpeech): She gives a pretty good one at  (SPOILER) The Battle of Whiterun

[Sarcastic Devotee](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SarcasticDevotee): Though she avoids outright insubordination, she's not afraid to explain to her superior in rather flat terms why his shallow knowledge of Nord culture will lead to disaster.
[Sergeant Rock](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SergeantRock): Not as much as Galmar of course, but she's tough enough.
