[We Used to Be Friends](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeUsedToBeFriends): Served with Galmar and Ulfric during the Great War, and still holds Galmar in high respect, but thinks Ulfric's gone mad with power. Ironically, however, she tries to use her former friendship with Ulfric as a last-ditch effort to persuade him to cease his rebellion, right after he pretty much takes Solitude. In the opposite situation, where Ulfric has his reckoning, she still bids him a final farewell after he lies dead. There are a lot of hints that show she can at least understand Ulfric's cause and her labeling him as a deluded ego-maniac is often contrasted with her lamenting that she must fight him. In essence, demonizing him (or at least trying to) may be her way of coming to terms with having to kill an old friend.
QUOTE **Legate Rikke**: Ulfric... my old friend... what have you done...

[You All Look Familiar](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouAllLookFamiliar): She isn't the Imperial captain who tries to execute you at the beginning of the game, but confusingly has the same armor set (occasional absence of the helmet notwithstanding) and voice actress (Claudia Christian, or " FemaleCommander " in the Creation Kit).
[Action Survivor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ActionSurvivor): One of the known survivors from Helgen.

tropeName: Come with Me If You Want to Live
tropeNotes:
[Come with Me If You Want to Live](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ComeWithMeIfYouWantToLive): At Helgen, if you have initial Imperial leanings.
QUOTE **Hadvar:** Still alive, prisoner? Keep close to me if you want to stay that way!
[It Gets Easier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItGetsEasier): Hadvar discusses this with you at one point, and wonders if it's really a good thing.
[The Lancer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheLancer): To a pro-Imperial Dragonborn.

[Nice Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceGuy):
    - He's visibly uncomfortable with executing people without cause, and honestly apologizes to you for the fact that his captain is insisting that you die alongside the Stormcloaks. He also won't hesitate to help you when a dragon arrives, regardless of your race. And while other Legionnaires are disturbingly gung-ho about killing Stormcloaks, he actually feels bad about killing his countrymen and wishes there could be a peaceful resolution soon. - Further, if you escape Helgen with him and follow him to Riverwood, he explains various things you pass, fights animals with you, invites you into his uncle's home, shares supplies, compliments you on your abilities, and says that as far as he is concerned, you have more than earned your pardon. He also advises you to avoid Imperial patrols until you meet General Tullius so that you are not mistakenly arrested again.
[Real Men Love Jesus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RealMenLoveJesus): In spite of the fact that it's outlawed by the Empire.

[Retired Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RetiredBadass): Following the conclusion of the Civil War with a Legion victory, Hadvar returns to his hometown of Riverwood, and will spend the rest of the game drinking quietly at the Sleeping Giant Inn.

tropeName: Screw the Rules, I'm Doing What's Right!
tropeNotes:
[Screw the Rules, I'm Doing What's Right!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScrewTheRulesImDoingWhatsRight): First shows signs of this when he objects to Helgen's Captain ordering your execution (the Captain sharply orders him to shut up), and shows it in full force when he offers to help you escape Alduin, despite the fact that you're technically a convicted "Stormcloak".
QUOTE **Hadvar:** Captain, what should we do? He's/She's [The Dragonborn] not on the list.<br data-format="\\"/>**Imperial Captain:** Forget the list. He/She goes to the block.<br data-format="\\"/>*[After Alduin begins his destruction of Helgen and Hadvar helps a young boy to safety while the boy's father is incinerated by Alduin]*<br data-format="\\"/>**Hadvar:** Still alive, prisoner? Keep close to me if you want to stay that way!
[Shell-Shocked Veteran](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShellShockedVeteran): Starts to show signs of this towards the end of the civil war questline.
[What Happened to the Mouse?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatHappenedToTheMouse): In the case of a Stormcloak victory, Hadvar's fate is never addressed, unlike General Tullius and Legate Rikke.
[Angrish](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Angrish): His last line before attacking you if you pay him a visit after  (SPOILER) you survive the attack on the Dark Brotherhood  turns into this.

tropeName: Did You Just Punch Out Cthulhu?
tropeNotes: [Did You Just Punch Out Cthulhu?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DidYouJustPunchOutCthulhu): He has a reaction along these lines if you kill Astrid and report it to him, thus beginning the quest to "Destroy the Dark Brotherhood!"
[Expy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Expy): Of Adamus Phillida, both being Imperial commanders that threaten the Dark Brotherhood.
[Good Parents](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodParents): His son is one of his officers, and Maro is very obviously proud of him.
[Hero Antagonist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroAntagonist): Seeing as the Dark Brotherhood commits many *exceptionally* monstrous crimes over the course of the game.

[It's Personal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItsPersonal): His primary motivation for going after the Dark Brotherhood, if you pursue that questline, is because  (SPOILER) by that point, you will have murdered his son and framed him for treason.
[Oh, Crap!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OhCrap):  (SPOILER) He does this if you choose to confront him after the raid of the Dark Brotherhood sanctuary.
[Papa Wolf](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PapaWolf): Don't mess with his kid.  (SPOILER)  The Dark Brotherhood finds this out ***[the hard way](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThePurge)***.
[Praetorian Guard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PraetorianGuard): The Penitus Oculatus serve as the Emperor's bodyguards.

[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): If you [Take a Third Option](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakeAThirdOption) at the beginning of the Dark Brotherhood quest, Maro  (SPOILER) gives you the password to their sanctuary and gets out of the way to let the Dragonborn do what they do best. Afterward, he's extremely grateful for the assistance, to the tune of 3,000 gold, and swears to tell the Emperor himself of the deed.  None of this changes even if the Dragonborn has already helped the Stormcloaks win the civil war.

[Retirony](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Retirony): After  (SPOILER) the Sanctuary massacre , he can be heard telling a subordinate that he plans to retire the second  (SPOILER) the real Emperor safely sets sail . However, killing him at this point is entirely optional.

[Roaring Rampage of Revenge](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RoaringRampageOfRevenge):  (SPOILER) He assaults and torches the Dark Brotherhood Sanctuary after his son is killed, slaying the majority of its inhabitants.
[Sarcastic Clapping](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SarcasticClapping):  (SPOILER) After the decoy Emperor is killed and he reveals his intentions.
[You Killed My Father](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouKilledMyFather): The Dark Brotherhood sanctuary suffers fiery vengeance for killing  (SPOILER) his son .

[Badass Longrobe](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassLongrobe): A unique set called "Emperor's Robes", a modified version of the standard Jarls' clothes with sleeves. They look cool and add to his badass image.

[Cool Sword](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolSword): According to rumors, he wielded the Daedric Artifact "Goldbrand" during the Battle of the Red Ring. This was never confirmed by the Empire itself.  (SPOILER) It's technically true and false: an impersonator took the place of the injured emperor before the battle, and said impersonator just so happened to have Goldbrand due to an encounter with Lord Naarifin the day before.

[Death Seeker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathSeeker): Bearing in mind that the Listener of the Dark Brotherhood killed a decoy before the Emperor was even in Skyrim, the Emperor very well knew he was targeted for assassination. He still sailed to Solitude after the death of that decoy anyway, calmly waited in his room, and faced his assassin with dignity and grace. Why he would do so is subject to little more than theories, but it is quite clear that he must have known he was going to his grave when he sailed to Skyrim, yet did so anyway.
    - He actually gives sort of an explanation when you talk to him. He's of the opinion that once the Dark Brotherhood targets someone, they cannot possibly escape, so he simply chose to face death on his own terms.

[Dying Moment of Awesome](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DyingMomentOfAwesome): The assassination of Titus Mede was supposed to put the Dark Brotherhood back on the map, but the sheer nobility he shows when he faces his death makes the assassination end up being the redemption of Titus Mede.

[Emergency Impersonation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EmergencyImpersonation):  (SPOILER) He was injured by assassins on the eve of the Battle of the Red Ring, so [he has The Forgotten Hero impersonate him by wearing his armor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ElCidPloy) so as to not to devastate the Legion's morale.
[The Emperor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheEmperor): Though a mostly personally nice one, even if you think he's a weak ruler.

[Face Death with Dignity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FaceDeathWithDignity): He takes his assassination remarkably in stride and the biggest "resistance" he puts up is a polite [Last Request](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LastRequest) to also kill whoever placed his contract.
[The Fatalist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheFatalist): He considers it inevitable that he will be assassinated and told Maro as such.

[Four-Star Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FourStarBadass): A talented general, he managed to encircle the entire Dominion army occupying the Imperial City during the Great War and obliterate it. He then captured Lord Naarifin, the Thalmor commander, and hung him from the White-Gold Tower, alive, for 33 days before having him killed. One account suggests the Thalmor commander was carried off by daedra on the 34th day.

tropeName: I Did What I Had to Do
tropeNotes: [I Did What I Had to Do](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IDidWhatIHadToDo): His, and by extension, the Empire's, justification for the White-Gold Concordat.

[Irony](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Irony): That an Emperor of Colovian descent (his ancestor was a Colovian warlord) is the one who banned the worship of Talos, the spiritual successor of Shor. Colovians are culturally, ethnically, and religiously Nordic.

[Last Request](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LastRequest): Before you kill him, he asks that you consider killing the man who ordered the contract on him in the first place. He's not particularly adamant that you do this and just listening to him will be enough.

[Pay Evil unto Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PayEvilUntoEvil): His decision to hang Lord Naarifin in a crow cage on the White Gold Tower for 33 days was brutal, but well-deserved. For the record, Naarifin planned to sacrifice the Imperial City's entire population to daedra.

[Rank Scales with Asskicking](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RankScalesWithAsskicking): If the stories about him fighting on the front lines are true.  (SPOILER) They're not quite true, but he *would've* been out there if it weren't for his injuries.
[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): Even if his political policies can be controversial, he is quite reasonable in person.

[Shut Up, Hannibal!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShutUpHannibal): If the Dragonborn attempts to intimidate him by declaring that Sithis commands his death, Titus simply tells them to cut it out and says that he has no intentions of dying like a coward.

[Vindicated by History](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VindicatedByHistory): In-universe, his decision to retreat from the Imperial City and link up with reinforcements from Skyrim. Those armies later crushed the Thalmor and saved the Empire from total destruction at the Battle of the Red Ring. His following decision of suing for peace with the Thalmor and signing the White-Gold Concordat, however, is subject to much more debate.

tropeName: Won the War, Lost the Peace
tropeNotes: [Won the War, Lost the Peace](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WonTheWarLostThePeace): Titus II ultimately accomplished his goal in making the Thalmor retreat from Cyrodiil, [but was unable to capitalize on that victory because his army and the Empire were in no condition to continue](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PyrrhicVictory). The White-Gold Concordat was the best he was able to get out of the Thalmor, but it wasn't acceptable to the Stormcloaks, hence the Civil War. Furthermore, the Concordat also ruined relations with Hammerfell, who rejected the treaty.
[You Can't Fight Fate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouCantFightFate): He believes that once you're targeted by the Dark Brotherhood, there is no escaping them.

[It's Personal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItsPersonal): At the very least, he hints at it. As far as he knows, the Thalmor killed some of his relatives during the "Night of Green Fire", and he is hell-bent on not giving them another inch in their struggle with the Empire.
[Large and in Charge](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LargeAndInCharge): As an Altmer, he towers over everyone else in his camp, and the effect is compounded by his heavy Imperial armor.

[Mauve Shirt](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MauveShirt): The only Legion hold commander who has anything to say beyond the bog-standard responses that all the others say. Legate Cipius in Whiterun may have things to say during the discussion with Jarl Balgruuf, but none of it is of a personal nature like Fasendil's dialogue.

[My Country, Right or Wrong](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyCountryRightOrWrong): Why he's in the Legion. The Empire isn't perfect, but he believes that it's the best Tamriel has, and the best way he can protect Tamriel is by being a Legionnaire.

tropeName: My Species Doth Protest Too Much
tropeNotes: [My Species Doth Protest Too Much](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MySpeciesDothProtestTooMuch): He's an Altmer Legate in the Legion, and has nothing but scorn for the Thalmor. He was in Hammerfell searching for relatives among the dissident refugees from Summerset on the "Night of Green Fire", where Thalmor agents decided to pursue the refugees into Hammerfell to slaughter them wholesale. Despite the best efforts of him and any other on-leave Legionnaires he could round up, it was for naught.<!--* PerpetualFrowner-->

[Physical Scars, Psychological Scars](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PhysicalScarsPsychologicalScars): He has a noticeable scar across his face. From the description he gives of his service, one wonders if his permanent scowl is due to typical Altmer haughtiness or from all the grim things he's seen in the service.

[Really 700 Years Old](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Really700YearsOld): He's served in the Legion for at least 160 years, as he mentions the Night of Green Fire as happening in 4E 42 and that he was in service at the time.
[Token Good Teammate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TokenGoodTeammate): He exists to offer definitive proof that not every High Elf is a genocidal totalitarian.

[A Child Shall Lead Them](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AChildShallLeadThem): Subverted. He's known as a "Boy-King", but in actuality, he's a fully-grown adult, though he is very young for the position of ruler of all Skyrim - hence the sobriquet.

[Alternate Character Interpretation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AlternateCharacterInterpretation): In-universe, you'll hear conflicting stories about him. One of Solitude's citizens says that he was an ineffectual king, while another expresses that he stamped down hard on crime and laments how things have deteriorated after his death. Another citizen describes him as constantly giving pro-Empire speeches, while his court wizard says he was close to declaring Skyrim's independence himself.

[Broken Pedestal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrokenPedestal): Several  NPCs , including [Sybille Stentor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FriendlyNeighborhoodVampire), will occasionally mention how Torygg seriously looked up to Ulfric. One or two will even comment how Torygg very well could have declared independence from the Empire himself had Ulfric asked him to. Instead, however, Ulfric grew more outspoken against the Thalmor himself, causing the Thalmor and Empire to clamp down and Ulfric to become a thorn in Torygg's side, until eventually Ulfric rode into Solitude, challenged Torygg to a duel, and killed him with the Thu'um.  (SPOILER) And if you meet Torygg in Sovngarde, he will be a touch bitter about the whole incident, see the quote under [Face Death with Dignity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FaceDeathWithDignity) below.

[Curb-Stomp Battle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CurbStompBattle): It's noted that even if Ulfric didn't have the Thu'um, he was an experienced veteran in his prime, while Torygg was a young man with limited martial training.

[Face Death with Dignity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FaceDeathWithDignity):  (SPOILER) The fact that he made it to [Sovngarde](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WarriorHeaven) shows that he died without fear when fighting Ulfric. 
QUOTE **Torygg:**  (SPOILER) I faced him fearlessly - my fate inescapable, yet my honor is unstained - can Ulfric say the same?

[Failure Is the Only Option](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FailureIsTheOnlyOption): Ulfric's public challenge for the duel trapped Torygg. Accept, and get easily beaten by a man ten times the warrior he was. Refuse, and be shamed throughout Skyrim and give Ulfric grounds to call a new Moot that very well might have named him High King. He chose the former, and  (SPOILER) earned his ticket to Sovngarde for it .

[Happily Married](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HappilyMarried): It seems that he and Elisif really did care for each other, as his death affected her deeply and  (SPOILER) he states that his only regret is leaving her a grieving widow.

[Hero-Worshipper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroWorshipper): He was stated to have the deepest respect for Ulfric, and might have declared Skyrim's independence had his idol just asked.  (SPOILER) By the time you meet him in Sovngarde, Torygg has nothing but scorn for the man he once admired.  Ulfric was unaware of this.
[Inadequate Inheritor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InadequateInheritor): Ulfric saw him as this, not entirely without reason, and held his father, Istlod, in far greater esteem.
[Posthumous Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PosthumousCharacter): He died prior to the beginning of the game.  (SPOILER) However, it's possible to meet him in Sovngarde.

[Sadistic Choice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SadisticChoice): A noteworthy war hero challenged him to a duel to prove his right to rule. Accept, and face near-certain death at his hands. Refuse, and live, but be humiliated and prove his point all the same. He opted for the former, and paid the price.  (SPOILER) But speaking to him in Sovngarde, he claims he doesn't regret it.

[Upper-Class Twit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UpperClassTwit): Several people in Skyrim, even those from his own hold, maintain that Torygg was nothing special. Testimony from a Redguard woman in Solitude:
QUOTE *If you ask me... he wasn't even a good king. All those rambling speeches about the Empire this, and the Empire that.*
[Asshole Victim](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AssholeVictim): Likely killed one way or the other, either by Alduin, by the Stormcloaks, or by the Dragonborn and Ralof's own hands.

[Death by Irony](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathByIrony): If you follow Ralof, then you encounter the captain and a subordinate trying to escape, and have to kill them. In such an event, the captain's overt hostility may have been a direct influence on the Dragonborn to join the Stormcloaks. For added irony, the very first weapon you'll pick up if you follow Ralof is an axe, which you'll have to go out of your way not to kill her with.
[Fantastic Racism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism): If you play as an Argonian or Khajiit, she refers to you with the slurs "lizard" or "cat."
[Jerkass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Jerkass): Hostile and belligerent to both Hadvar and the Dragonborn.
[Killed Off for Real](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KilledOffForReal): Definitely is if you follow Ralof, and likely even if you don't.
[No Name Given](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoNameGiven): Only ever referred to as "Imperial Captain".

[Nice Job Breaking It, Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceJobBreakingItHero): Whether it's this or [Nice Job Fixing It, Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceJobFixingItVillain) depends on how you view the civil war, but what's certain is that she does *not* help the Empire's case by trying to execute some random civilian for the crime of being in the vicinity of Ulfric at the wrong time:
    - She wanted to make sure Ulfric and his lieutenants were going to be executed, to the point of ordering the death of an [Innocent Bystander](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InnocentBystander) ([the Dragonborn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayerCharacter)) just to be sure. Although it is ultimately up to the player, that incident incited *a lot* of players to join [the Stormcloaks](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LaResistance), as well as making the Empire look like a bunch of bloodthirsty, oppressive invaders in the eyes of newcomers to the *Elder Scrolls* series (which are likely many, considering *Skyrim*'s numerous re-releases over the years). Threads discussing the motivations to join one side over the other will often be littered with *"I joined the Stormcloaks because the Imperials tried to cut my head off!"* Hell, given that the game [will have Hadvar act as if you escaped with him if you joined the Empire, even if you escaped with Ralof](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameplayAndStorySegregation), it's not uncommon for players who plan on joining the Empire to escape with Ralof *just for the chance to kill her*. - Basically, just her being so obnoxious could have cost the Empire the entire civil war. Tullius had Ulfric captured and about to be executed, so the civil war was basically over. Then by acting like a complete [Jerkass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Jerkass) even in the wake of Alduin's attack, she draws the ire of the Dragonborn, potentially sending them on a warpath that involves joining up with the Stormcloaks and kicking the Empire out of Skyrim virtually all on their own. - Had Alduin *not* chosen that moment to show up, she would've doomed *the entire world* as there would have been no Dragonborn to counter him.
[Obstructive Bureaucrat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ObstructiveBureaucrat): Orders the Dragonborn's execution, against Hadvar's objection that they aren't on the list.

[What Happened to the Mouse?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatHappenedToTheMouse): If you follow Hadvar, then she isn't seen again for the rest of the game. Tullius comments that "not many people made it out of Helgen," implying that she may have died regardless.
[Colonel Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ColonelBadass): As noted above, a Legate seems to be the rough equivalent of a Colonel in authority.

[Cultural Posturing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CulturalPosturing): In their "why you should join the Imperials" speech, they show some disdain for Nordic culture, opining that the Jarls can't actually control their own people, leaving it to the Empire to do so. Becomes a little weird when it's one of the Nord legates saying it.
[Made of Iron](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MadeOfIron): Due to being marked as essential, even after the end of the war.

[Multinational Team](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MultinationalTeam): Emphasizing the Empire's cosmopolitanism in contrast to the Stormcloaks' Nord nationalism, these legates include two Nords (three, including Rikke), four Imperials, one Breton, one Altmer, and one Dunmer.
[The Remnant](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheRemnant): If the war is won for the Stormcloaks, the Legates and their camps stay around.
[Square Race, Round Class](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SquareRaceRoundClass): All of them belong to the Soldier class, even the Breton and the elves.
[Video Game Cruelty Potential](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VideoGameCrueltyPotential): Their inability to die makes them great for grinding various magical or combat skills.

[Asskicking Leads to Leadership](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AsskickingLeadsToLeadership): Stormcloak officers are chosen based on individual fighting skill, so the commanders tend to be mighty chieftains and warriors in their own right.

[Badass Army](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassArmy): They're more informal and less regimented than the Legion, but compensate for this by individually being stronger and more skilled warriors. This is unsurprising since most of them come from the eastern half of Skyrim, where young Nords must kill an ice wraith as a rite of passage. If you join them, Galmar has you do the same to prove your worth.
[Badass Cape](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassCape): Stormcloak officer armour has a bear-hide cloak attached.

[Badass Creed](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassCreed): *Fight or die well.* As Nords they also use a general Nord battlecry, "Victory or Sovngarde!" Not to mention the oath one has to take before they officially join the Stormcloaks ranks.
QUOTE **Stormcloak Oath:** I do swear my blood and honor to the service of Ulfric Stormcloak, Jarl of Windhelm and true High King of Skyrim. As Talos is my witness, may this oath bind me to death and beyond... even to my lord as to my fellow brothers and sisters in arms. All hail the Stormcloaks, the true sons and daughters of Skyrim!

[Band of Brothers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BandOfBrothers): In comparison to the somewhat more hierarchical atmosphere of the Legion, every Stormcloak is the shield-brother of the man next to him, causing these men to be fiercely loyal to one another.

[Barbarian Heroes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BarbarianHero): They have this vibe to them. The people of Whiterun do point out that the Stormcloaks are generally rowdier than the old Whiterun guards; and being Nords, they aren't the most sophisticated bunch around. [Carlotta Valentia](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeadTurningBeauty) will bemoan that Whiterun's old guards may have pestered her constantly, but they at least had the courtesy to groom themselves.

[Bears Are Bad News](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BearsAreBadNews): Their main [Animal Motif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AnimalMotif). The Stormcloak Officer's uniform (which the player is awarded upon being named  (SPOILER) Stormblade ) includes a cloak fashioned from a bearskin, complete with head, and there's a bear's head on their flag. The bear seems to be the official hold animal of Eastmarch (similar to the horse for Whiterun and the wolf for Haafingar), so that may be the reason.

[Bomb-Throwing Anarchists](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BombThrowingAnarchists): How the Empire at large views them, considering them a minor and rather insignificant and aimless insurrection that has simply been allowed to persist for too long, compared to the threat that the Thamlor and the Aldmeri Dominion poses. Admittedly, this view has actually worked to their advantage as it is only very recently, after about two decades of the Civil War being mainly minor skirmishes and guerrilla warfare, during which the Stormcloaks have enjoyed plenty of time and opportunity to slowly build up their strength, that the Empire has seriously begun to invest resources into an attempt to stamp them out, at a point where it might be too late.

[Bullying the Dragon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BullyingTheDragon): Subverted. The Empire as a whole is *much* stronger than the Stormcloaks. If you play the Dark Brotherhood and Stormcloak storylines simultaneously, Ulfric will refuse to attack Solitude so long as the Emperor, or his cousin Vittoria Vici, is present. He knows full well that though killing them might be a short-term victory, but it would mean that with the high profile murder of their ruler, the Empire would no longer have any excuse to ignore the threat of the Stormcloak Rebellion, and would have to bring the full might of the Imperial military down upon them, which would all but certainly result in a quick and crushing defeat for the rebels. The Stormcloak Rebellion can only succeed because the Empire does not consider it a serious enough threat to invest anything but the barest minimum amount of force possible in suppressing it, allowing them to keep the majority of their forces on the border with their equal-strength rival, the Aldmeri Dominion. In the end, the Empire as a whole considers the prospect of losing Skyrim a regrettable, but ultimately acceptable loss compared to giving any semblance of an opportunity to the Dominion.

[Fantastic Racism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism): A common criticism of the Stormcloaks is their nativism as it often encourages rampant racism in their group, with varying degrees of accuracy.
    - Part of this is just due to general background intolerance among Skyrim's Nords. All the holds, Imperial or Stormcloak, ban the Khajiit caravans from entering. "Skyrim belongs to the Nords" is a popular battlecry among Nords both within and without the Stormcloaks and Skyrim society, in general, doesn't think too highly of elves due to a long history of warfare between the races, with the Great War being only the most recent example. So whether a random Stormcloak is more racist than a random Nord is an open question. - The Stormcloak-aligned jarls have different reasons for supporting the Stormcloaks, ranging from loyalty, nativism, and to personal gain.
      - Laila Law-Giver has two Bosmers in her court (one is her steward while the other is a court mage). She supports the Stormcloaks solely because she believes Ulfric's claim to the throne is legitimate and is mostly ignorant of her people's needs. She does have doubts about Ulfric but puts these feelings aside. - Skald the Elder is paranoid about Imperial spies in his hold, something The Empire is known to do. He does have a Breton, Madena, as his court mage. - Korir is openly distrustful of magic and sides with Ulfric because he's the only one who listens to his concerns. He does have a Dunmer as a steward but he only employed him because he wrongly assumed Malur Seloth was connected to The College of Winterhold. - Dengeir of Stuhn supports the Stormcloaks because he believes they care more about Skyrim than the Empire does, even if he distrusts Ulfric's motives for the war. - Vignar Grey-Mane only cares about Skyrim's beliefs and traditions, he makes it clear to Jarl Balgruuf the Greater that it's nothing personal and he would have left well enough alone if the Empire had just allowed him to worship Talos without fear of torture. When he becomes the Jarl of Whiterun, his family will occupy Dragonsreach. - Thongvor Silver-Blood hates The Empire for creating the White-Gold Concordat with the Thalmor and believes he's being shunted aside by the Jarl. His steward is an Imperial, Reburrus Quintilius, who was presumably chosen because of his financial skills. The Silver-Bloods are more concerned about profit and eradicating the Forsworn.
    - Windhelm, as the seat of Ulfric's power and thus most directly shaped by his policies, is seen as an example of what Stormcloak-run Skyrim will look like. The city has vast racial inequalities with rampant bigotry; [its version of the introduction to the city scene the major Holds get](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EstablishingCharacterMoment) features two Nords threatening a Dunmer woman. The Dunmer are forced to live exclusively in the ghetto of the Gray Quarter and are a clear underclass to the Nords, while the Argonians are treated even worse and aren't allowed into the city. However, while Ulfric is established to be apathetic to the struggles of the Dunmer, it's also pointed out that a large, destitute refugee population moving into a city is going to be at a financial and social disadvantage and the Dunmer's problems are partially their own fault for their refusal to assimilate. - The Stormcloak leadership officially has no problems with other races, they simply value loyalty to Skyrim which Nords logically tend to have more of. Unofficially, there is a clear Nord bias in their thinking. Ulfric holds that all "True Nords" will support them and Galmar states that he fights because he refuses to let elves rule over men. A Dragonborn of any race will be asked why they wish to fight for Skyrim, with a Nord having the question of why a foreigner would care as opposed to the other races being asked why a member of their race would care. Even an Altmer Dragonborn can become a high-ranking and well-regarded warrior for the cause, but how much of this is them [being one of the good ones](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouAreACreditToYourRace) is open to interpretation. - The rank and file have a wide degree of variation in terms of racism, from those that think highly of other races and simply want Skyrim to be politically independent to those who openly disdain any non-Nords and yearn specifically for Nords being back on top.

[Good Old Ways](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodOldWays): The Stormcloaks are fighting to preserve their traditions and they believe the Thalmor are being given too much power over Skyrim. Their stated goals include: Lifting the ban on Talos worship across Skyrim, expelling or executing all the Thalmor Justiciars who have been granted the authority by the Empire to enforce the White-Gold Concordat within the province, crown Ulfric Stormcloak the High King of Skyrim, and independently prepare Skyrim for a future war with the Aldmeri Dominion. A common criticism of the movement is how to some members the good old ways include racism and intolerance towards other races.

[Honor Before Reason](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HonorBeforeReason): They want to preserve their Nord traditions and culture from the Thalmor, however, they are still planning to start another war with the Aldmeri Dominion and are actively xenophobic towards Mer and Beast races.

[Humanity Is Superior](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HumanityIsSuperior): In general, the Stormcloaks are far less arrogantly assured of their own superiority than they simply are unrelenting foes of all things elven and have a similar hatred of those whom they perceive as having sided with them against Mankind, such as the Imperials. They have a clear distaste for Beastfolk, however, and refuse to allow them into their city of Windhelm, but this could have mitigating factors (not the least of which being that the two Khajiit governed kingdoms at least are actually a part of the Aldmeri Dominion).

[Informed Attribute](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InformedAttribute): One element of their racism gets this through [Gameplay and Story Segregation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameplayAndStorySegregation). When the Stormcloaks conquer Whiterun, Adrianne Avenicci states that they tend to do business exclusively at Nord-run shops and that she would have gone out of business if she wasn't married to a Nord. However, given the [Space Compression](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpaceCompression) that results in most cities only having one or two of each type of shop, this would result in crippling the player's ability to do business in those cities if this was put into practice. To avoid biasing the player towards the Empire for strictly economic/convenience reasons, the non-Nord shops will continue to operate without difficulty and will have just as much money as they always have to buy your loot.

[Insult Backfire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InsultBackfire): In the earliest stages, the Imperials began calling them Stormcloaks as a means to ridicule them and their allegiance to Ulfric. They took the name happily, due to their great admiration for their leader.

[Manly Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManlyMan): They're [Vikings](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ProudWarriorRace) who are fighting in the name of and to restore the worship of their principal God of War; their basic initiation test requires them to kill an undead wraith creature on an iceberg in the middle of the sea; and they have names like Stone-Fist, Sun-Killer, and Cairn-Breaker.

tropeName: A Nazi by Any Other Name
tropeNotes: [A Nazi by Any Other Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ANaziByAnyOtherName): Downplayed. As a faction of fair-haired nationalists and nativists led by a charismatic war veteran with a penchant for hammy speeches, the comparison makes sense. However [the Stormcloaks are much more sympathetic in their goals and actions than the Thalmor, and also much less racist to non-Nords than the Thalmor are to non-Altmer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackAndGrayMorality). A non-Nord Dragonborn, even an Altmer, can be accepted among their ranks, provided they prove their loyalty to the cause of an independent Skyrim kingdom.

[Nice Job Breaking It, Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceJobBreakingItHero): Characters note that until the Stormcloak uprising, the Empire quietly turned a blind eye to the continuance of Talos worship in their territories. Once Ulfric and the Stormcloaks came onto the scene, the Dominion established their embassy in Skyrim and began weeding out Talos worshipers personally, and the Empire had to start cracking down to keep up the truce.
    - The Thalmor actually *wanted* them to start the Civil War as it would weaken the Empire's army, giving the Aldmeri Dominion an advantage in the Second Great War. - It's also worth noting that the Civil War was the final thing that the prophecy stated had to happen before the return of Alduin.

[Noble Bigot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NobleBigot): Their racism aside, their primary target is the Thalmor, who forced them to give up their beliefs, traditions, and tribal identity under the threat of torture and execution.

[Order Versus Chaos](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OrderVersusChaos): A possible way to view the conflict between the Empire and Stormcloaks, respectively. Legates and pro-Imperials tend to lean towards this view in particular when it comes to war and the Stormcloaks, with the Empire representing Order and the Stormcloaks representing Chaos.
[Proud Warrior Race](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ProudWarriorRace): All Nords are this, but the Stormcloaks are more intense about it.

[Rank Scales with Asskicking](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RankScalesWithAsskicking): All their leaders. Ulfric's basically a poster boy for the [Warrior Prince](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WarriorPrince) trope who's noted as basically the kingdom's greatest warrior save possibly for the Dragonborn himself. Even his fiercest detractors, like Brunwulf Free-Winter, admit he's a mighty warrior and a great leader. Galmar is a [savage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ProudWarriorRaceGuy), [fur-clad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NemeanSkinning), [berserking](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheBerserker) giant of man who chops down Thalmor and Imperials like lumber with an effin' huge battleaxe.

[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): The Stormcloak chain of command is rather benevolent and efficient. As long as you prove yourself useful, you'll be treated the same as anyone else, regardless of race or fighting style.

tropeName: The Revolution Will Not Be Civilized
tropeNotes: [The Revolution Will Not Be Civilized](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheRevolutionWillNotBeCivilized): Zigzagged; many people in Imperial Skyrim sympathize with their cause and admit Ulfric is not a bad man, but side with the Empire because they believe in honour, revere tradition, and/or acknowledge that the Empire will be needed when the next war with the Thalmor comes. Others see the Stormcloaks as barbarian rebels needing to be put down. In Stormcloak holds, most champion Ulfric and the Stormcloaks as Skyrim's liberators, but some also see Ulfric in a less-benevolent light and mention that they side with him only because they see him as the [Lesser of Two Evils](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LesserOfTwoEvils) compared to the Empire.

[Romanticism Versus Enlightenment](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RomanticismVersusEnlightenment): The Romantic side of the conflict. The Stormcloaks are a band of barbarian brother warriors led by a controversial [Byronic Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ByronicHero) [Warrior Prince](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WarriorPrince) fighting to liberate their homeland and restore its honour. Their ideology leans heavily into traditionalism and nativism, but it carries an undercurrent of xenophobia and anti-intellectualism as well.

[Screw You, Elves!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScrewYouElves): They are very open about their hatred for the Dominion, which [is fully justified](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ANaziByAnyOtherName). Many of their supporters unfortunately direct this vitriol towards other elves as well, such as the Dunmer or non-Thalmor Altmer, despite both groups being persecuted by the Thalmor and the latter [despising them](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MySpeciesDothProtestTooMuch) just as much as the Stormcloaks do.

[Spanner in the Works](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpannerInTheWorks): By launching a bid for Skyrim's secession from the Empire, they are drawing the Legion's already slim manpower and resources to putting them down when they are trying to rebuild for the inevitable second war against the Thalmor. That said, the Stormcloaks can also be this for the Thalmor if they win the war decisively; their victory in the civil war leads to a hostile independent Skyrim that can build up armies and defences and resume Talos worship free from their prying eyes.

[Token Minority](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TokenMinority): A non-Nord Dragonborn can count as one if they join the Stormcloaks. Also, it's possible to find random encounters of a Redguard, or even an Imperial, arriving to Windhelm to join the Stormcloaks. They justify this by saying they believe (as many other pro-Stormcloak individuals do) that the Empire has fallen into decay and therefore unfit to rule Skyrim. However, there aren't any non-Nord Stormcloaks (except potentially the Dragonborn) that are seen anywhere in the game, though this is primarily due to engine constraints.

[Well-Intentioned Extremist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WellIntentionedExtremist): The Stormcloaks as a whole truly do believe that the Empire's time has passed and Skyrim (especially the Nords) must assert her independence under a stronger High King if they are to survive as a culture.

[With Us or Against Us](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WithUsOrAgainstUs): Many of them have this attitude. If you ask Galmar why you should join, he turns the question around and tells the Dragonborn that if they don't already know the answer, they should probably leave quickly.

[Affably Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AffablyEvil): Can come off this way to Imperial-aligned players. When you deliver Balgruuf's axe, he praises your bravery. You are then free to ask him questions about his backstory, and he responds candidly. The end of his boss fight also proves that he respects you.

[Alternative Character Interpretation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AlternativeCharacterInterpretation): In-universe, a lot of different people have a lot of polarizing things to say about Ulfric and his true motivations in killing Torygg and rebelling against the Empire. Is he a heroic freedom fighter, a cowardly usurper, a well-meaning but misguided patriot? Depends who you ask. Ulfric himself shows himself to be a complex and layered person — at times he acts humble and doubts his worthiness, other times he shows himself to be confident and bold regarding his rebellion. This is because he's well aware that his actions and his reputation can affect the morale of forces on both sides of the warlines, but which of them is the *real* Ulfric is up for debate.

[And There Was Much Rejoicing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AndThereWasMuchRejoicing): Both ways.
    - Traditionalist and nativist Nords in Imperial-aligned territories have this reaction when he and his warriors defeat the Empire. - (SPOILER) The more outspoken parts of the Dunmer and Argonian population in Windhelm have a similar reaction if he is killed.

[Animal Motif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AnimalMotif): Ulfric is associated with bears; in Markarth, he's referred to as "The Bear of Markarth" and his army has adopted a bear as the emblem of their rebellion.

[Anti-Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiHero): He may seem a bit ruthless and slightly xenophobic at times, but in the long run he is just trying to maintain Nordic integrity. Given the situation, any headstrong Nordic leader would be slightly Nationalistic during these times.

[Authority Sounds Deep](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AuthoritySoundsDeep): Of all the initial Jarls in Skyrim, Ulfric has the deepest voice. Among his fellow Stormcloaks, he commands a tremendous amount of authority.

[Badass Family](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassFamily): [This is Skegglund Stormcloak. He's one of Ulfric's ancestors](http://www.imperial-library.info/content/arms-and-armor-nordic-champion-skegglund-stormcloak). Also, as a Jarl of Skyrim, he possibly has a line of descent going straight to Shor-damned Ysgramor himself. According to Mera Stormcloak, Thane of Windhelm and daughter of the Guard Captain, the Stormcloaks have a habit of being more badass than their already badass forebears.
    - After winning the war, Ulfric names a Stormcloak aligned Dragonborn "Stormblade". While the game treats it as simply another rank, the similarities to Ulfric's own surname and uniqueness of the title could imply he intends it as giving you a cadet clan to the Stormcloaks, the closest a nobleman can come to legally adopting the Dragonborn as a sibling.
[Badass Longcoat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassLongcoat): As mentioned above, it's made of chainmail and plate. However, it has an abysmal armor rating, so it's basically worthless as protection.

[Base-Breaking Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BaseBreakingCharacter): An in-universe example. Skyrim itself is massively divided in their opinion on him, and, depending on whom you speak to, he will be presented as anything from a visionary hero to a power-hungry megalomaniac. Notably, there are also people that consider him a nobleman, but oppose his rebellion (f.e. Legate Rikke), and people that don't like him much personally, but support his war effort (f.e. Dengeir of Stuhn), making him the game's by far most complex case of [Alternative Character Interpretation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AlternativeCharacterInterpretation).
[Beard of Barbarism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BeardOfBarbarism): Well, he *is* a Nordic warlord.

[Berserk Button](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BerserkButton): The Thalmor in general, and Elenwen in particular. His dislike for Elenwen is so intense that during "Season Unending," if you agree to kick her out of the peace conference, it is considered a major concession on the Stormcloak side, and Ulfric will be willing to yield a minor hold to the Empire in exchange for it. In other words, Ulfric is willing to give up an entire hold just so he doesn't need to be in the same room as Elenwen. The fact that Elenwen is the main architect of the Thalmor inquisition that oppresses Talos-worshippers also has something to do with it.
QUOTE **Ulfric:** You insult us by bringing *her* to this negotiation?! Your chief Talos hunter?!
[Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad): If you side with the Empire, then he's this for the Civil War questline.
[Big Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigGood): Should you join the Stormcloaks, he's the one directing you against the Legion throughout the war.

[Blatant Lies](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlatantLies): After a Stormcloak victory, Ulfric declares he will not claim the throne of High King unless he's elected so by the Jarl's Moot. This is after he led an army sworn to obey him as the "true High King" in a war to replace every Jarl in Skyrim with his supporters. Even Galmar points out afterwards that he's only paying lip service to the idea.
[Blood Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BloodKnight): The good Jarl enjoys combat a great deal. In fact, he even lets out bellowing laughs while in combat.
[Blown Across the Room](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlownAcrossTheRoom): Ulfric is fond of using Unrelenting Force in combat.

[Bodyguarding a Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BodyguardingABadass): Galmar fulfills this role, to an extent. Galmar can't send you flying several feet with a mere words, or make your weapon jump out of your hand with other mere words.
[Braids of Barbarism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BraidsOfBarbarism): Has these too.

[Broken Pedestal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrokenPedestal): In life, King Torygg idolized him.  (SPOILER) When you meet him in Sovngarde, he has nothing but scorn for the man who killed him and left his wife Elisif a grieving widow.
[Byronic Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ByronicHero): Let's see... Gifted? Check. Intelligent? Check. Charismatic? Check. Yet deeply flawed all the same? That too.
[The Chains of Commanding](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheChainsOfCommanding): He does regret some of the things he's had to do in this war.

[Cold Ham](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ColdHam): For somebody at the head of an entire army of [Hot-Blooded](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HotBlooded) [Proud Warrior Race Guys](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ProudWarriorRaceGuys), Ulfric himself is remarkably subdued; and even when he is shouting, he sounds very distant and impersonal (in stark contrast to Tullius, who is a standard [Large Ham](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LargeHam)). [Fridge Brilliance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FridgeBrilliance) kicks in when you realize that this comes most likely from his Greybeard training - he knows that raising his voice can have unintended consequences.

[Combat Pragmatist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombatPragmatist): He had no problem using the Thu'um against Torygg, who stood almost no chance against Ulfric anyway. This bites him in the ass, however, as what would have been a lopsided fight instead split the continent over what was perceived as a dishonorable move by some.

[Create Your Own Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CreateYourOwnVillain): The Thalmor tortured Ulfric and set him loose as a controlled asset, figuring that he would start a war for Skyrim's secession from the Empire and drain Imperial resources to give Alinor an advantage in the second war. However it would seem that they underestimated Ulfric's charisma, leadership ability and strategic acumen.

[Death by Irony](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathByIrony): He can be killed instantly with Unrelenting Force, the exact same shout he used in his "duel" with Torygg, if you retake Windhelm with the Imperial Army.

[Decapitation Presentation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DecapitationPresentation):  (SPOILER) Possibly a victim of it the end of the Imperial campaign. After defeating him, Tullius express his desire to take Ulfric's head and send it to the Imperial City, and then have it skewered on a pike and put on display outside the city walls as [an example of how the Empire deals with traitors](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MakeAnExampleOfThem).

[Defiant to the End](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DefiantToTheEnd): At the end of the Legion questline, he refuses to quietly surrender and *will* stand and face you alongside Galmar. He will go down fighting, of course, and once he's beaten this leads to the trope below.

[Deadpan Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker): We get this gem if you ask him whether his curb-stomp of Torygg constitutes murder or not:
QUOTE **Dovahkiin**: There are those who say that you murdered the High King.<br data-format="\\"/>**Ulfric**: I challenged him to a duel, and he accepted. True, he was no match for me.

[Dick Dastardly Stops to Cheat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DickDastardlyStopsToCheat): Accounts of his duel with Torygg agree that he used the Thu'um against him. Pro-Imperial characters not only think this was an act of despicable cowardice, but also unnecessary since Ulfric could have beaten him easily on even ground.

[Dirty Coward](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DirtyCoward): Some Imperial-aligned characters call him this, citing things like his use of the Thu'um against Torygg when he was ten times the warrior the Boy King was and everyone knew it. Though, according to Ulfric himself, the death blow was dealt by his blade and his use of the Thu'um was only to stun Toryg prior to the killing blow.

[Divided We Fall](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DividedWeFall): Realizes it when  (SPOILER) you meet his spirit in Sovngarde, if you finish the Civil War before the main quest. Stormcloak or Imperial, what does it matter when both sides are being devoured by Alduin, and those in the realm of the living are going to die by his hand no matter what flags they fly? He laments that he's found this wisdom too late to do anything with it.
[Don't Create a Martyr](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DontCreateAMartyr): At the end of the Imperial questline, Tullius expresses concern that killing Ulfric will end up doing this.

[The Dreaded](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDreaded):
    - The Empire *and* the Thalmor fear him with good reason. - He's also hyped a lot in the Imperial campaign as a mighty warrior and master of the Thu'um. - When Elenwen, the head of the Thalmor in Skyrim and perhaps the most powerful person sitting at the (SPOILER) peace meeting , decides to drone out a [Hannibal Lecture](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HannibalLecture), Ulfric tells her in no uncertain terms to shut up. And she *does*.

[Face Death with Dignity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FaceDeathWithDignity): If the player sides with the Empire, at the end of the siege of Windhelm, Tullius tells Ulfric he could surrender and be publicly executed, or go down fighting. Ulfric chooses fighting, of course. When beaten down and kneeing, he issues his [Last Request](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LastRequest) — that the Dragonborn be the one to deal the final blow, since "it'll make a better song that way."

[Fantastic Racism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism): [Very downplayed example](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DownplayedTrope). He's apathetic to the problems of non-Nords and makes it clear that he'd prefer a Skyrim without the other races. But if you ask him about it when joining the Stormcloaks as a non-Nord, he notes that race isn't anywhere near as important as *loyalty*, so the matter is simply that he doesn't think non-Nords are as loyal to Skyrim as Nords are. His nativism appears to be more rooted in his belief that Skyrim's best interests should be performed by its inhabitants, not the likes of the Empire and elves.

[Fatal Flaw](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FatalFlaw): He tends to quickly escalate to violence. The Thalmor are using him as an [Unwitting Pawn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnwittingPawn) because they judged that he would skip any attempt at diplomacy and go straight to a violent rebellion, even though he and the Empire ultimately share the same goals, and any attempt at talking through their problems would have made this obvious. Thus, he'd polarize Skyrim, turn the Empire's attention away from the Thalmor, and make both sides easy pickings in the end.

[A Father to His Men](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AFatherToHisMen): He values his followers' lives, which is why he's extremely cautious about attacking Whiterun. He also tries to non-violently coax Balgruuf into siding with him; even though the two men dislike each other personally, Ulfric doesn't want to kill the people of his hold. After the Stormcloaks conquer Solitude, he denies credit for the victory and instead calls the soldiers and the Dragonborn the true heroes of the war.
[Foil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foil): To the Dragonborn's [Crystal Dragon Jesus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CrystalDragonJesus), particularly if the player joins the Empire.

[Four-Star Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FourStarBadass): He's managed to keep complete control over half of Skyrim, despite the Empire throwing all they have at him, - including one of their best generals.

[Front Line General](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FrontLineGeneral): During the Battle of Solitude. Cut content in the Creation Kit reveals that he was initially supposed to be involved in the siege of every major Hold capital, including Whiterun, for which there are dialogue files of him giving the same speech Galmar gives before the battle begins.

[The Good King](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheGoodKing): [Metaphorically True](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MetaphoricallyTrue). Ulfric is basically everything Nords would want in a king - unstoppable in battle, generous to his followers, honourable, extolling courage and strength and punishing cowardice and weakness and just the right amount of savage. Hell, even Brunwulf Free-Winter, his fiercest critic, can't find a flaw in his character beyond his racism and even outright admits that Ulfric is a great warrior and a great leader. If it wasn't for the guy's apathetic attitude towards the plight of non-Nords, he'd be a model King. As it stands, he's still a model *Warrior*-King.

[Gone Horribly Right](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoneHorriblyRight): The Thalmor want Ulfric to be an [Unwitting Pawn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnwittingPawn) who weakens the Empire by stirring up a costly Civil War... but they don't want the Stormcloaks under Ulfric to *win*. With some Dragonborn assistance, Ulfric can become the High King of a very well-armed, pissed-off nation of warriors who have a serious axe to grind with the Dominion.
[Good Scars, Evil Scars](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodScarsEvilScars): Former if Stormcloak, latter if Imperial.

[Hazy-Feel Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HazyFeelTurn): Used to be a proud soldier of the Imperial Legion. During the Great War he participated in retaking the Imperial City but was taken as a war prisoner, and then watched as Emperor Titus Mede promptly surrendered to spare Cyrodiil further fighting, submitting Skyrim to terms that he considered unacceptable and spitting on the sacrifices his people made to take the city back. Embittered by the perceived betrayal, Ulfric was offered a deal he could not refuse by Jarl Igmund of the Reach: raise a militia to retake Markarth from the Reachmen and free worship of Talos in the city would be restored. When Ulfric obliged, the Imperial authorities (under pressure from the Dominion) reneged their terms and arrested him. This was the last straw for Ulfric - he lost all faith in an Empire he now saw as a crumbling shadow of what it once was, full of Thalmor appeasers and unworthy successors who demanded the blood of the Nord people but would not bleed for them, and so he began to plot a rebellion to drive them out of Skyrim for good.

[Heroic BSoD](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicBSOD): If the Civil War is ended in the Imperials' favor before  (SPOILER) the final confrontation with Alduin, he can be seen in the throes of one while trapped in Alduin's Soul Snare in Sovngarde, watching as good men and women who fought on both sides of the war, the war that he started no less, are devoured to empower the World-Eater.
[Hidden Depths](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HiddenDepths): According to the Creation Kit, he's friends with Scouts-Many-Marshes.

[Hypocrite](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Hypocrite):
    - His rebellion is partly based on the importance of Skyrim's traditions being followed, which under the Empire they are not. However, in his discussion with Galmar about the Jagged Crown, his reaction to being told the Moot might well name Elisif to the throne of High King anyway is an emphatic "Damn the Jarls, and damn the Moot." This punctuated during his victory speech, where he piles on the false modesty by refusing to declare himself King until the Moot formally names him as such, even though the Moot is now transparently rigged in his favor. - There is also the fact that he cut his teeth as a field commander against the Forsworn, whose grievances against the Nords mirror the Nords' against the Empire pretty exactly. - His description of High King Torygg can easily be boiled down to describing him as an inept weakling. Yet Ulfric, in spite of his superior combat skill and experience, used the Thu'um to incapacitate Torygg before dealing the killing blow.

[Informed Flaw](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InformedFlaw): According to the Construction Set, Ulfric's Speech skill is set at only 20, but you wouldn't know it from listening to any of his dramatic and evocative [Rousing Speeches](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RousingSpeech).

[It's All About Me](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItsAllAboutMe): A few characters, such as Hadvar and Jarl Laila's son Saerlund, believe that Ulfric's real goal is to become king of Skyrim. He responds to Galmar suggesting the Jarls might elect Elisif at the Moot in spite of a Stormcloak victory with "Damn the Jarls... And damn the Moot!" The oath would-be Stormcloaks have to take has them swear their loyalty to him as "the true High King." At the end of the Imperial-sided Civil War, he decides that he'd rather be killed by a mythical hero like the Dragonborn, rather than some Imperial like Tullius. Should you carry the day with the Stormcloaks, Galmar himself expresses exasperation with Ulfric over drawing out Tullius' impending death, saying that if he wants the end to a saga he should get the Dragonborn to kill him. In the end, whichever of these various points are true is up to the player to decide.
[Jerkass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Jerkass): Primarily from his racism. His uncompromising attitude towards Imperial-leaning Nord leaders likewise can make him seem like this.

tropeName: Jerk with a Heart of Gold
tropeNotes: [Jerk with a Heart of Gold](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkWithAHeartOfGold): But there is certainly nobility and honor in his heart nonetheless. Notably, for all the racism accusations from both Imperial-leaning characters in-universe and Imperial-leaning players out of it, he's willing to accept a non-Nord Dragonborn into his ranks without any issues and is generally very approachable in the Stormcloak Campaign. He also shows shades of his honorable side during the Imperial Campaign as well since he considers the Dragonborn a [Worthy Opponent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WorthyOpponent) again regardless of race.

[Jerkass Has a Point](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkassHasAPoint): Invoked and discussed on the opposite side of the war; quite a few people in the western portion of Skyrim feel he's right on certain matters and sympathize with him due to his ideology if nothing else. One example of these is Raerek — a steward to an Imperial-aligned Jarl. Similarly,  (SPOILER) Tullius, at the end of the Stormcloak campaign and before his execution, admits that for all his hatred of them, the Stormcloaks do have several salient points regarding the Legion and Skyrim's future. If he shows up during Elenwen's party during the main quest, he'll even go so far as to say that it almost makes him want to join them. Almost. 
QUOTE **Raerek:** So. You're one of Ulfric's spies... I can't deny the man is right about a few things...

[Just the First Citizen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JustTheFirstCitizen): Despite being the effective ruler of nearly half of Skyrim before the civil war questline begins, and possibly being the ruler of *all* of Skyrim after, Ulfric is simply called "Jarl," a title appropriate to the ruler of a single hold. He says he wants to wait for the Moot to elect him, as tradition dictates.

[Karmic Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KarmicDeath): Twice.
    - The civil war began when Ulfric used the Thu'um in his duel with Torygg. The player can use the Thu'um to finish Ulfric off if they side with the Empire, even using the same one (Unrelenting Force). - If the Dragonborn is a Dunmer then it's poetic how a dark elf is the one to finish him off. In Windhelm, Dark Elves are second-class citizens due to being refugees and Ulfric is purposefully indifferent to their suffering. The same is true for an Argonian, as they're not even allowed in the city, and are stuck in a slum on the docks.

[Large Ham](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LargeHam): He gives a hell of a speech, and likes his victories and defeat to be magnificent and worthy of remembrance if possible. It should be noted that he doesn't let this love for the dramatic encroach upon practical military stratagems, and he has no illusions about the [negative aspects of war](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WarIsHell). That said, when this man wishes to make a speech, a speech shall be made! Complete with growling, shouting, and testosterone-laced rhetoric.

[Make an Example of Them](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MakeAnExampleOfThem): "Torygg was merely a message to the other Jarls." Related to this, Galmar and Balgruuf mention that if Ulfric wanted, he could just challenge the other Jarls and kill them to earn the right to rule their holds much as he challenged Torygg, taking over Skyrim personally. But now Ulfric seeks to prove the power of the Stormcloaks, not his Thu'um, likely to prove to everyone including Skyrim herself that the country can stand up to the Thalmor without the Empire, as so many doubt.
[Make Me Wanna Shout](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MakeMeWannaShout): He was training to be a Greybeard. He learned two Shouts before he left them: Unrelenting Force and Disarm.
[Magic Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicKnight): Thanks to the above trope, though he's first and foremost a warrior.

[Manipulative Bastard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManipulativeBastard): He can be quite cunning when he wants to be. How much so depends on how much credit you're willing to give him, with Imperial-aligned characters frequently considering his rhetoric about fighting for Skyrim's traditions and apparent humility to be fronts he uses to gain support. Even without this interpretation, there are moments like his challenge to Torygg. Ulfric and his followers claim the duel wasn't a murder since both men agreed to fight, while members of Torygg's court note that, if Torygg had actually refused, Ulfric could have used that as proof he was unfit to be High King and called a Moot to depose him. There is also the issue that in Nord culture, that while challenging someone to a formal [Duel to the Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DuelToTheDeath) is an acceptable way to settle a conflict, it is also generally viewed as an incredibly harsh way of doing so and only something that should be done in the event that all attempts to find a diplomatic solution to said conflict have been exhausted; something which Ulfric's critics will notice he *didn't* do before challenging Torygg. In his speech to his troops after winning the Civil War, he refuses to take the position of High King until elected by the Moot. A minute later in private, Galmar praises that "nice touch" and Ulfric confirms he knows his election is guaranteed.

[Manly Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManlyMan): A Viking king who believes in [Asskicking Leads to Leadership](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AsskickingLeadsToLeadership) and who kills people by shouting at them.

[Messianic Archetype](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MessianicArchetype): To a good portion of Skyrim; he's the one who shall overthrow a corrupt and failing Empire, drive out the Thalmor, and restore the country to glory under the banner of a new, stronger leader. His role as a Windhelm Jarl warring with elves after taking part in the civil war is highly reminiscent of Ysgramor, the King who founded the First Empire and built Windhelm along with many of the ruined cities in the Hold, while his skill with the Thu'um echoes several past Emperors, including Tiber Septim, a.k.a. Talos himself, the Dragonborn who founded the Third Empire that's currently in power. All things considered though, Ulfric and his supporters *don't* play up Ulfric's similarities to past rulers as much as they could. Or at all, really, given Ulfric commenting he hopes he proves worthy of his father's throne that was once Ysgramor's.

[Memetic Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MemeticBadass):
    - In-universe example. An extremely sizable portion of Skyrim treats him like he's the Second Coming. Hilariously, "second coming of Talos" is a phrase some NPCs use to describe him. QUOTE *"They say that Ulfric Stormcloak murdered the High King... with his Voice! Shouted him apart!"* - According to what most first-hand sources (including Ulfric himself) say, he did use the Voice when he killed the High King, but the actual killing blow was done by hand.

[Metaphorically True](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MetaphoricallyTrue): His response to allegedly shouting Torygg to death is that it's "Not entirely true, though not entirely false, either." In essence, he knocked Torygg down with a Shout and stabbed him in the heart.

[Missing White Woman Syndrome](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MissingWhiteWomanSyndrome): Brunwulf Free-Winter accuses him of having this mentality, stating that Ulfric will only lift a finger to deal with the bandits and marauders in his hold if their victims are other Nords, while attacks on Dunmer, Argonians or Khajiit go totally ignored.
[Modest Royalty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ModestRoyalty): Unlike most other Jarls, he doesn't even wear a crown.

[Mr. Exposition](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MrExposition): Out of all of the Jarls, he likely has the second deepest connection to the main quest aside from Balgruuf; he's the only Jarl who can tell you anything of the Greybeards in detail and, short of the Greybeards themselves, anything about your destiny as the Dragonborn in detail. Justified, since he's a traditionalist and a former Greybeard in training.

tropeName: My God, What Have I Done?
tropeNotes: [My God, What Have I Done?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyGodWhatHaveIDone): If killed before finishing the main quest,  (SPOILER) Ulfric can be found wandering Alduin's mist in Sovngarde. If spoken to before killing Alduin, he laments that he wanted to free Skyrim but all his war did was kill good men on both sides - and now those men's souls are trapped in Alduin's mists, waiting to be devoured by the World Eater.

[Never Heard That One Before](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NeverHeardThatOneBefore): You get the feeling from his tone of voice that he's about as sick [as you are](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WelcomeToCorneria) of Imperial sympathizers and others claiming that he murdered Torygg or 'shouted him apart'. Such as it is, you can  (SPOILER) meet up with Torygg in Sovngarde, and he more or less confirms it was a legitimate duel... though he contests it being "honorable".
[Neutral No Longer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NeutralNoLonger): While training to be a Greybeard, he was unable to detach himself from the world's affairs as they do and left to help fight the Thalmor.

[Nice to the Waiter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceToTheWaiter): A bit of [hidden depths](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HiddenDepths) here; he's very approachable in the Stormcloak campaign and should you prove yourself true to the cause, he will call you his blood-brother and will be remarkably candid with you regarding his past. Additionally, when you talk to Galmar after your initiation, he will say that while he didn't truly expect you to return, Ulfric vouched for you to him and even made a bet saying that you would succeed. When you end conversation with him, Ulfric says for you to 'Go with the Gods', urges you to be careful in Skyrim and offers up the time-honored wisdom of 'keep your brother, and he'll keep you'. He will also do this regardless of your race. So, you could be an Imperial or Altmer or Argonian and he'll still treat you with the same kind of brotherhood and dignity. Note that this is *only* during the Stormcloak campaign. If the player doesn't offer to join the Stormcloaks during their first conversation, any subsequent attempts to speak with Ulfric have him threaten to throw you in prison for bothering him until the player does agree to join his cause.
[Noble Bigot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NobleBigot): Depending on how the player feels about him, he can come across as this. In his campaign, he certainly does.

[No Badass to His Valet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoBadassToHisValet): The relationship between Ulfric and Galmar is less a king to his general, and more like the friendship between fellow war veterans - which they are.
QUOTE **Galmar:** They call themselves Stormcloaks because they believe in you. Because they're the meanest, toughest sons of bitches Skyrim has to offer. And they want this. They want it as much as you. Perhaps they want it more.

[No Historical Figures Were Harmed](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoHistoricalFiguresWereHarmed): Interestingly, Ulfric has quite a lot in common with [Robert the Bruce](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/UsefulNotes/RobertTheBruce). His killing of Torygg with the Voice and the controversy over the morality of the action closely mirrors Bruce killing John Comyn on holy ground to kickstart his own rebellion.
    - He also shares many startling similarities to the real life Alaric the First, king of the Visigoths. Alaric started his early life as a high-ranking soldier leading a band of Goths in the Roman army, and he later left in disappointment citing a lack of recognition from the Romans for the sacrifices of his men in defence of their country. He led a rebellion against Rome and managed to pull it off, even sacking Rome in 410 AD, an event which caused Rome a great deal of damage to their prestige and eventually led to the empire's decline.

[No Sympathy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoSympathy): He's described as apathetic to the problems of non-Nords, to the point that Brunwulf Free-Winter sends the Dragonborn after a group of bandits because, since they only target non-Nords, Ulfric is ignoring them.

[Overrated and Underleveled](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OverratedAndUnderleveled):
    - The game practically turns Ulfric into a king-slaying, [Thu'um throwing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LoudOfWar) [Memetic Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MemeticBadass), if dialogue is to be believed. Yet when an Imperial-aligned Dragonborn storms his castle, Galmar is harder to kill than he is. - The [Doylist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Doylist) reason takes this trope literally. Up until patch 1.6, all NPCs were leveled based on when the player first encounters them, and they never changed except in special circumstances. Ulfric is the third character seen in the opening sequence, and thus is locked at level 10. So, you're fighting what would be a challenging enemy, *if you were at level 1*. - Even with the patch that buffs Ulfric's health, his outfit possesses a whopping **7** armor rating (at level 1, even an outfit of hide armor is better), so any decently-skilled character will wipe the floor with him.
[Patriotic Fervour](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PatrioticFervour): His modus operandi - and by extension, that of the Stormcloaks.

[Poor Communication Kills](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PoorCommunicationKills): Ulfric was unaware that Torygg admired him enough that he would have given declaring Skyrim’s independence serious consideration if Ulfric had just opted to discuss it with him. Ulfric, for better or worse, jumped the gun and chose the more extreme option.

[Power Nullifier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PowerNullifier): He's tightly gagged when you first encounter him on the cart to Helgen, which is later revealed to be a precaution to prevent him using the Thu'um to escape Imperial custody.
[Proud Warrior Race Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ProudWarriorRaceGuy): Because True Nord.

tropeName: A Pupil of Mine Until He Turned to Evil
tropeNotes: [A Pupil of Mine Until He Turned to Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/APupilOfMineUntilHeTurnedToEvil): In a sense. Ulfric learned the Thu'um from the Greybeards, but he violated the Way of the Voice when he used the Thu'um to kill King Torygg (he was already a far more capable combatant than Torygg without the Thu'um). However, he admits that he's aware he's strayed from their teachings, and does believe the Thu'um should not be used lightly.

[Rank Scales with Asskicking](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RankScalesWithAsskicking): Ulfric is the leader of the Stormcloak rebellion and one of the fiercest warriors in Skyrim. He expects this of other leaders also, offering this reasoning for his actions at the Blue Palace. Somewhat tellingly, out of all the Jarls in the game, Ulfric is the *only* one who actually acts like a Germanic king.
QUOTE **Ulfric:** I killed him to show our miserable condition. How could Torygg protect his people if he couldn't even protect himself?

[Real Men Love Jesus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RealMenLoveJesus): He's a worshiper of Talos, of course; that's a big part of why the Stormcloaks are rebelling. And just to drive the point home, the local priest in Windhelm will mention that he's a very regular temple-goer.
[Red Oni, Blue Oni](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedOniBlueOni): The blue to Galmar's red.

[Reluctant Ruler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReluctantRuler): If you ask him about his past, he'll say that after his beloved father died, the hold of Eastmarch basically put him on the throne as soon as he got out of prison for the Markarth Incident, being at one with his own grief. He ends the conversation by praying he proves worthy of the honor. Zigzagged when it comes to his goal of becoming High King. It's very clear that he intends to rule, even having his men swear loyalty to him as the "True High King" but how much of that is because he wants to rule as opposed to feeling he needs to is open to interpretation. If asked, he basically sums up their motivation as "[Skyrim needs heroes, but instead, it has us.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SelfDeprecation)"
QUOTE "The throne of Ysgramor... The throne of my father... I can only hope that I prove worthy of it."

[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): Playing through the Stormcloak campaign shows him to be not the power-hungry tyrant Tullius paints him to be, but rather a driven, understandable and determined man with noble intentions at heart.

[Rousing Speech](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RousingSpeech): He gives a lot of them. At the end of his campaign, he gives arguably his best one and is rather self-conscious of it. But that was less due to some political aim and rather because he really wanted to give the men a bang. It also plays into his love for Wagnerian-esque drama.

[Royals Who Actually Do Something](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RoyalsWhoActuallyDoSomething): Zig-zagged. On the one hand, he's spearheading a war in the name of Skyrim's independence and is one of the few Jarls who isn't consumed by hedonism or disfunction and has the clout to get things done. Yet on the other hand, with said war consuming all of his attention, he's become neglectful of many domestic matters (such as the [Serial Killer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SerialKiller) at large in Windhelm).

[Shut Up, Hannibal!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShutUpHannibal): Should Elenwen be allowed to to remain at the Greybeard's Council, either he or Tullius will give her one when she tries to dismiss Esbern's speech. She listens.

[Slouch of Villainy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SlouchOfVillainy): While everyone who uses a throne (except Elisif) takes this position, Ulfric stands out for two reasons: firstly, he ends up as the civil war's [Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad) if the player takes the Empire's side; and second, since his throne was originally built for Ysgramor, it's *huge* and making him look like he's slouching more than he actually is.

[Social Darwinist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SocialDarwinist): One of Ulfric's arguments against the Empire is that he firmly believes that Skyrim should be a land of the strong, yet the Nords' past reliance on the Empire has weakened them.
