[Missing Mom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MissingMom): She died when he was a little child.
[Nice Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceGuy): To the point where he's actually *enthusiastic* about helping you carry stuff. Really, he's almost too nice to become a feared mercenary.

[Mythology Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag): One of his ancestors may have been a [guard in Cyrodiil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/TheElderScrollsIVOblivion), since he'll say in combat, "This is the part where you fall down and bleed to death!"

[Pet the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PetTheDog): The Dragonborn can offer to pay for his armor, so his father won't go into debt.
    - [Or you can just threaten his father.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KickTheDog)

[Red Baron](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedBaron): "The Slayer". Erik explains that his father wanted him to take a sobriquet that fits him, but he chose this one to make himself seem more impressive to potential enemies. After all, no one's gonna quake in fear of ["Erik Greenthumb" or "Erik Hoe-Pusher"](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AtrociousAlias).
[Small Town Boredom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmallTownBoredom): Why he wants to be an adventurer.

[Strong Family Resemblance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StrongFamilyResemblance): He looks a fair bit like his father, the owner of the village inn. He inherited his mother's eye and hair color, presumably, as those don't match. And hopefully his mother's hair retention, as Mralki is bald on top.

[Video Game Cruelty Potential](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VideoGameCrueltyPotential): Completing his quest makes him not only available as a follower, but also as a husband. He's also one of the characters who can become a steward in *Hearthfire*. There is absolutely nothing keeping the player from enacting any of the two latter options as soon as they become possible, then never, ever, having him as a follower while traveling.
[Badass Normal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassNormal): He can only level up to level 30 and he doesn't know any magic, but he's so good with his bow that it often doesn't matter.
[Deadpan Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker): "Riverwood's agreeable enough, I suppose. For a Nord village."

[Disc-One Nuke](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DiscOneNuke): Getting him as a follower is not only possible within five minutes of leaving Helgen, but he's also a trainer, and as a companion you can get Archery lessons from him and then take back the gold from his inventory for free lessons. Enjoy having your pumped-up bow skills deal a [One-Hit Kill](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneHitKill) to early enemies.

[Love Triangle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LoveTriangle): With Sven over Camilla. He's no better and no worse than Sven; both of them hatch a *completely identical plot* to win over Camilla's affections: write a forged note insulting Camilla and make it look like the other guy wrote it, so Camilla will turn on him and fall for the forger instead. Faendal's letter is the more blunt, being essentially a [Stylistic Suck](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StylisticSuck) poem on [Stay in the Kitchen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StayInTheKitchen), while Sven more or less depicts Faendal as a stereotypical Thalmor elf.

[ Never Hurt an Innocent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NeverHurtAnInnocent): His morality is set to 3 (will not commit any crimes), which means he'll turn on the Dragonborn if they instigate a fight with a civilian.

[Nice Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceGuy): All [Love Triangle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LoveTriangle) issues aside, he's perfectly happy to help you out, he's extremely loyal to the point where he never objects if you turn him into a pack mule, and he's got none of the [Fantastic Racism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism) most of his species does.

[Would Not Shoot a Civilian](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WouldNotShootACivilian): Ask him to kill a civilian and he will say, "Not for you, not for anyone." Kill one yourself without due cause (basically in cold blood) and he'll join the guards in killing you. If one of them attacks you first, however, he'll side with you since they started it.

[Abusive Dad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AbusiveDad): His dad locked him in Hillgrund's tomb for three days. It's an ambiguous example, however, because the note from his aunt says that it was actually his *brother* who did it. So it's hard to say what actually happened in that specific instance (to muddy the waters further, the Unofficial Skyrim Patch changes the note to say it *was* his father), but Dad sounds like a nasty piece of work regardless, to judge by some of his other comments. <sup>note </sup>  The aunt's note may contain a dev typo - if Agna is Golldir's paternal aunt, it's possible that the sentence was supposed to say "since my brother locked you in there".
[Disappeared Dad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DisappearedDad): But that may be for the best. His dad was a drunken bastard.

[Fantastic Racism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism): [Defied](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DefiedTrope); when describing what the Necromancer (a Dark Elf) is doing to his ancestors, he talks about "filthy Dark Elf Necromancy". [If the Dragonborn is a Dark Elf, however](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouKnowImBlackRight), he will immediately add that there was "no offense intended", as he assumed they weren't in that kind of practice.

tropeName: Luckily, My Shield Will Protect Me
tropeNotes: [Luckily, My Shield Will Protect Me](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LuckilyMyShieldWillProtectMe): He prefers a axe and shield fighting stance and has the "Deflect Arrows" perk and receives little damage from them.
[Nice Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceGuy): Wants to clear a family's crypt inhabited by a necromancer that's an enemy of his family.

[What the Hell, Hero?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatTheHellHero): Calls the Dragonborn out if they steal treasure from his family's ancestral tomb. He reluctantly agrees that they can keep it as a reward for helping him out, but he's clearly *not* happy about it.  <sup>note </sup>  Even if they *don't* take anything, he'll say this in response to their merely looking into one of the containers, which is a little frustrating if the player accidentally clicks on an urn.
[Affably Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AffablyEvil): She makes no bones about being a killer, but she also likens it to an art and generally remains polite and professional about it.

[Aristocrats Are Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AristocratsAreEvil): If she's taken into a mine, she'll bemoan the fact that the very people who dig up precious minerals are so poor, implying she's of upper class status.
[Blood Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BloodKnight): Jenassa enjoys fighting and killing a lot, but only if paid and in the service of a worthy employer.
[Combat Aestheticist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombatAestheticist): She gushes over the aesthetics of blood spray, and describes combat as "making great art".
[Dual Wielding](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DualWielding): One of the few followers who prefer dual wielding over using a shield.
[In Love with Your Carnage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InLoveWithYourCarnage): She can be married after being hired.

[Leeroy Jenkins](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LeeroyJenkins): Regards you as being this if you go into a Draugr crypt with her.
QUOTE **Jenassa:** Few would dare to trespass in these ruins. What you lack in wisdom, you make up for in courage.
[Professional Killer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ProfessionalKiller): She works as a bodyguard for hire, but also thinks like an assassin in her methodology.

[Stealth Expert](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StealthExpert): She has one of the better sneak skills for followers in the game, and will frequently advocate sneak kills or tricking enemies while in fort ruins.
[Übermensch](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Ubermensch): Has strongly held views which are uniquely hers, and is very outspoken about them.
[Berserk Button](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BerserkButton): If you complete the love triangle quest in Faendal's favor, he becomes very frosty towards you.

[Joke Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JokeCharacter): He's a cowardly twit who lives with his mom, he's one of the weakest fighters, and he has the shortest span before he can stop leveling up, only going to 20, the lowest except for Roggi Knot-Beard, who also only levels to 20. It's one of the reasons that he often gets snubbed and people travel with [Faendal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DiscOneNuke). The one real upside he has is that he's willing to commit crimes, and even then that's very situational when the Dragonborn could just do it themself.

[Love Triangle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LoveTriangle): Both Sven and Faendal are competing for Camilla's affections. Sven is no better and no worse than Faendal; both of them hatch a *completely identical plot* to win over Camilla's affections: write a forged note insulting Camilla and make it look like the other guy wrote it, so Camilla will turn on him and fall for the forger instead. Faendal's letter is the more blunt, being essentially a [Stylistic Suck](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StylisticSuck) poem on [Stay in the Kitchen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StayInTheKitchen), while Sven more or less caricaturizes Faendal as a stereotypical Thalmor elf.

[Not Now, Kiddo](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotNowKiddo): At first, he believes his mother is crazy for thinking a dragon attacked Helgen. He takes it back (though not to her face) if you inform him there really *was* a dragon.
[Overshadowed by Awesome](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OvershadowedByAwesome): Faendal usually gets chosen over Sven, since Faendal is both a trainer and levels to 30 vs. Sven's 20.

[Quirky Bard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/QuirkyBard): Sven's job is to stand around in an inn and keep people entertained with music. Are you really surprised in any way that he's terrible in combat? Well, [you can always just sacrifice him to Boethiah](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainProtagonist).

[Real Men Wear Pink](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RealMenWearPink): Sort of. Sven is a bard and plays in the Sleeping Giant Inn. That's the "pink" of this trope. He's also a lumberjack, as dialogue from Hod reveals that he works at the town's sawmill. That's the "real men" of this trope.
[Action Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ActionGirl): Implied by her love of fighting, and her attempt to join the Companions.
[Best Her to Bed Her](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BestHerToBedHer): It's possible to marry Uthgerd, but only if you defeat her in a fistfight first.
[Blood Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BloodKnight): Fighting is one of the things that makes her happy.

[Brawn Hilda](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrawnHilda): A female Nord warrior with rough facial features, whose starting gear includes a bulky armor, and who can only be hired after being defeated in a fist fight. She's probably not supposed to actually be *un*attractive in-universe, since she's one of the potential spouses.
[Defeat Means Friendship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DefeatMeansFriendship): To get her to follow you, you need to defeat her in a brawl.

tropeName: Desperately Looking for a Purpose in Life
tropeNotes: [Desperately Looking for a Purpose in Life](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DesperatelyLookingForAPurposeInLife): To an extent, she's this; the only thing that seems to make her at all happy is fighting.  (SPOILER) She's a popular choice for recruitment into the Blades, because it means she can spend the rest of her life doing exactly that.

tropeName: Does Not Know Her Own Strength
tropeNotes: [Does Not Know Her Own Strength](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DoesNotKnowHerOwnStrength): To the point of beating someone to death in a practice fight.

[Drowning My Sorrows](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DrowningMySorrows): Assuming you don't recruit her for some adventures, she spends 24 hours a day drinking quietly in a corner of the Bannered Mare in Whiterun. She will never even visit the house she owns in the city.
[The Lad-ette](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheLadette): Due to buggy AI, she just stays in the inn drinking all day.
[Proud Warrior Race Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ProudWarriorRaceGuy): In true Nord fashion.
[Stone Wall](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StoneWall): She has steel plate armor at the start.

[Underestimating Badassery](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnderestimatingBadassery): She claims that the Companions purposefully sent a "young whelp" to fight her for practice because they underestimated her for being a woman. She ended up killing him by accident. [Of course, this sort of sexism is never shown, other than maybe the Empire having no female troops](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShowDontTell), and none in the Companions, with 2 of the 4 members and 1 of the 4 of the Circle being women, plus the Dovahkiin if they're a woman.
[Dark Is Not Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DarkIsNotEvil): Azura is a Daedric Prince, but she's one of the nicer ones. Aranea is completely loyal to her and is quite nice herself.

tropeName: Desperately Looking for a Purpose in Life
tropeNotes: [Desperately Looking for a Purpose in Life](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DesperatelyLookingForAPurposeInLife): After Azura informs her she won't receive any more visions, she's left lost, not knowing what to do, and decides to join you as a result. Unlike some of the other followers in a similar situation, like Illia, she's not an option for Steward in *Hearthfire*; however, she can be  (SPOILER) recruited into the Blades .

[Gameplay and Story Segregation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameplayAndStorySegregation): If you decide to  (SPOILER) turn Azura's Star into the Black Star , Aranea will threaten to kill you any time you return to the shrine, but will never actually attack.
[High Priestess](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HighPriest): Of Azura.
[Hot Witch](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HotWitch): She's cute for a Dunmer, who usually have pretty harsh features.

[Really 700 Years Old](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReallySevenHundredYearsOld): It's implied she was one of the original pilgrims that built the Shrine, over two centuries ago. She likewise mentions that Azura granted her a vision foretelling the Dragonborn's arrival at the Shrine, long before they were even *born*.

[Undying Loyalty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UndyingLoyalty): She is the only follower of Azura who remained at the statue after waiting a couple hundred years. Even after Azura stops giving her visions and she decides to join you, she will still stay at the Shrine in her free time to pursue her duties as a High Priestess.
[Made of Iron](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MadeOfIron): Starting in steel plate, he makes a great tank.
[Memento MacGuffin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MementoMacGuffin): His Moon Amulet was a gift from his mother when he was very young.

tropeName: My Species Doth Protest Too Much
tropeNotes: [My Species Doth Protest Too Much](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MySpeciesDothProtestTooMuch): Unlike most Khajiit (including J'Zargo, the only other Khajiit follower, and even his own employers, who can become fences for the [Thieves' Guild](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThievesGuild) late in the questline), he refuses to do *anything* illegal if you ask him, stating that "even Khajiit have their limits".

[Nice Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceGuy): One of the few Khajiit who is genuinely friendly to the Dragonborn. Even when asking you to retrieve his amulet, he warns you to be careful, noting that as much as he misses it, he doesn't feel it's more valuable than your life.
[The Nose Knows](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheNoseKnows): Played with. "If anyone tries to sneak up on us, I will smell them coming. Or... I might not. We will see."

[Off the Wagon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OffTheWagon): Kharjo advises you that drinking and gambling do not mix - whatever he did when he combined the two resulted in him landing in prison. Akhari got him out and he is repaying the debt by guarding the caravan.

[Crazy-Prepared](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CrazyPrepared): Ghunzul doesn't simply use himself and his bandits to protect the shards. He keeps them locked in the dungeon, protected by several button-activated bars, numerous tripwire traps, and spikes that stab at anyone who opens the chest containing them.
[Old Soldier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OldSoldier): When was the last time you saw an Orc with *white* hair?
[Retired Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RetiredBadass): The book *The Keepers of the Razor* suggests he once served in the Imperial Legion.
[Secret-Keeper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SecretKeeper): He is the eighth descendant of the Inner Circle that shattered Mehrunes' Razor and divided the fragments across Skyrim.
[The Atoner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheAtoner):  (SPOILER) He was a Dominion battlemage, and he's now a Priest of Arkay to atone.
[Cool Old Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolOldGuy): One of the nicest Altmer you will meet in Skyrim.

[Cultural Rebel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CulturalRebel):  (SPOILER) He's very grateful for the friendship and respect the humans of Falkreath have shown him during his time there. Contrast this with his former masters in the Aldmeri Dominion, who would love nothing more than to see humanity wiped off the face of Nirn.

[Dreaming of Things to Come](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DreamingOfThingsToCome): Runil has a dream portending the coming of Alduin, and of his own eventual path-crossing with the Dragonborn. His first scene in your presence has him giving last rites over a grave, just as his dream foretells.
[Good Shepherd](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodShepherd): As a priest of Arkay, the god of birth and death, he presides over funerals and comforts the family and friends of the deceased.

[Heel–Faith Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaithTurn): He explains that he became a follower of Arkay  (SPOILER) and presumably defected from the Aldmeri Dominion  after the Great War, feeling the weight of all the people he killed and hoping to be redeemed.
[Retired Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RetiredBadass): A veteran of the Great War who's still quite skilled.

[Shell-Shocked Veteran](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShellShockedVeteran): Much like Madena, he's got some shell shock over all the lives he terminated during the Great War with his magefire.  (SPOILER) His journal indicates he was on the Aldmeri Dominion side, who weren't known for holding back in the magic department either.
[Summon Magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SummonMagic): He is the common-level Conjuration trainer.
[The Atoner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheAtoner): He admits that he probably deserves to die for what he's done, and if you choose to spare him, he promises to never return to society.

[Blessed with Suck](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlessedWithSuck): Hircine's Ring was supposed to allow him to control his transformations, but thanks to Hircine cursing it as revenge for his theft, it ended up causing him to transform randomly and lose even more control over his transformations.

[Did You Just Scam Cthulhu?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DidYouJustScamCthulhu): Attempted to get one over on the Daedric Prince Hircine by stealing Hircine's Ring. It didn't turn out well for him since Hircine cursed the ring to make his transformations completely uncontrollable.

tropeName: Does This Remind You of Anything?
tropeNotes: [Does This Remind You of Anything?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DoesThisRemindYouOfAnything): Sinding's description of his werewolf instincts taking over at the sight of little girl sounds a lot like a child predator recalling an assault. As repentant as he is, he almost sounds excited during the telling.

[Sadistic Choice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SadisticChoice): Either kill him under Hircine's orders and get new armor or help him kill the other hunters and gain the uncursed Ring of Hircine. [Or do both](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakeAThirdOption), to exploit a bug to get you both rewards.
[Tragic Monster](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TragicMonster): He didn't want to murder the child, but owing to Hircine's curse he ended up doing so against his own will.
[Walking Shirtless Scene](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WalkingShirtlessScene): Since he's a werewolf he goes around shirtless all the time.
[Aloof Archer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AloofArcher): An aloof hermit who lives in the wilderness, honing her archery skills on any foolish bandits that come close.

[Don't You Dare Pity Me!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DontYouDarePityMe): Part of the reason why she lives outside of society. Offer your sympathies after she tells you her story and she'll get angry.
QUOTE **Angi:** Don't be like them. Don't feel sorry for me.
[Doomed Hometown](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DoomedHometown): She was born and raised in Helgen.

[Friendly Sniper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FriendlySniper): First impressions notwithstanding; she threatens to put an arrow in your head when you first meet her, but that's only because most of the people visiting her shack are either trying to rob her or kill her. If you act friendly towards her, she happily teaches you her formidable archery skills, gives you her personal bow when you pass all her tests, and thanks you for keeping her company.
[The Hermit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHermit): Lives alone on a mountain ridge, but doesn't mind.

[Kick the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KickTheDog): Can be on the receiving end of a *major* one from the Dragonborn; see "[You Have Outlived Your Usefulness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouHaveOutlivedYourUsefulness)" below.
[Master Archer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MasterArcher): So skilled with a bow that she's one of the only three master archery trainers in Skyrim.
[Only Friend](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OnlyFriend): The Dragonborn can become this to her.
[Roaring Rampage of Revenge](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RoaringRampageOfRevenge): She made sure the two drunk Imperial soldiers that killed her family got what they had coming to them.

[You Can't Go Home Again](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouCantGoHomeAgain): Implied, even before Helgen was destroyed. The Imperial Legion probably wasn't too happy when she murdered those two soldiers, justified or not. Good thing she already wanted to leave town.

[You Have Outlived Your Usefulness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouHaveOutlivedYourUsefulness): After she has taught the Dragonborn everything she knows about archery and offered them her special bow as a parting gift, the player can tell her that [she is of no more use to them](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KickTheDog) and they are now going to [kill her](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UngratefulBastard).

[Affably Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AffablyEvil): She's extremely polite to the Dragonborn and pays them well if they chop firewood for her. If she likes the Dragonborn, she'll even let them have free lumber as long as they cut it themselves. That being said, she's still a vampire who feeds off of travelers.

[Ambiguously Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmbiguouslyEvil): Really, it's hard to determine how evil she is. Yes, she's a vampire... but she seems to just want to live on her own with her husband. Her dialogue implies that some of her victims have been Imperial soldiers that were patrolling and were "nosy", but the specifics aren't given. Did they stumble upon her bloody murder shed and see past victims? Did they realize she was a vampire and try to kill her for the simple reason of **being** a vampire, so she and her husband killed them in self-defense? Or did she murder them in cold blood after luring them in? Even the extent of her victims isn't known. Were they travelers, merchants, and other innocent people? Or does she prey upon bandits, necromancers, and other scum that won't be missed from society? She and her husband don't seem to care much for other vampires, going by the fact that if the Dragonborn is a blood-starved one they'll become hostile to you. But at the same time, their ability to walk in the sun without issue indicates that they have been feeding regularly — people, venison, trolls, cattle.
[Cute Monster Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CuteMonsterGirl): She's this in the vanilla game. [Not so much](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NightmareFace) with *Dawnguard* installed, though.
[Cut Lex Luthor a Check](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CutLexLuthorACheck): She actually makes an honest living selling lumber.

[Karma Houdini](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KarmaHoudini): If you choose to destroy the Dark Brotherhood rather than join it, you can never get the quest directing you to kill her and her husband and they'll be free to keep killing innocent travelers. Since they're not marked essential, however, you *can* kill them independently of the quest, though the game will simply treat it as common murder in spite of their wickedness.

[Schmuck Bait](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SchmuckBait): Some of her random dialogue will have her offer to let you stay the night, although you have no way to accept this. Lucky for the Dragonborn, as the various fed-upon corpses in the basement reveals what happens to those who do.
[Unholy Matrimony](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnholyMatrimony): She's married to Hern, another vampire and a Dark Brotherhood contract.
[Evil Old Folks](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilOldFolks): Again, she's a witch.
[Faux Affably Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FauxAffablyEvil): When you first meet her, she remarks on how nice it is to have a visitor. She even has the typical "friendly old lady" voice set.
[He Knows Too Much](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeKnowsTooMuch): If you go snooping around in her basement, she'll attack you when you come back out.
[Most Definitely Not a Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MostDefinitelyNotAVillain): When you talk to her, she may say that she's just a poor old woman with nothing interesting.
[One Degree of Separation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneDegreeOfSeparation): Her sister is Moira, the Hagraven to whom the Dragonborn  (SPOILER) gets drunkenly engaged to  during "A Night to Remember".
[Hypercompetent Sidekick](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HypercompetentSidekick): Of Siddgeir. He's too lazy to run the hold, so he has her run it, which she does well.
[Nice Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceGirl): She's nice and does her best to look after the people of Falkreath.

[Older Than They Look](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OlderThanTheyLook): She served under Dengeir when he was young, and now Siddgeir, but she still looks very young. Justified, since she is a Altmer, who can live for hundreds of years.

[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): She runs Falkreath Hold, due to Siddgeir being disinterested in actually running it and she truly does what's best for the people.
[Right Hand Woman](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RightHandWoman): Of Jarl Siddgeir, and Dengeir before him. She runs the day-to-day operations in the Hold.
[Shout-Out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShoutOut): She shares her name with [Galadriel's ring of power](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Literature/TheLordOfTheRings).
[Statuesque Stunner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StatuesqueStunner): She's very cute for a Altmer and she towers over every other non-Altmer.

[Amazon Brigade](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmazonBrigade): A particularly horrifying example; his undead minions, be it draugr or ghosts, are all female, and it's heavily implied that he [sleeps with them](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ILoveTheDead).
[Evil Sorcerer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilSorcerer): A very perverted [necromancer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Necromancer) who kills women and turns them into his undead slaves.

[Karmic Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KarmicDeath): A stealthy Dragonborn can sneak behind his throne and remove the soul gem that controls his guards or shoot it off the pedestal with an arrow, [turning them against Arondil and killing him](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HoistByHisOwnPetard).
[I Love the Dead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ILoveTheDead): While it's never outright said out loud, his diaries heavily imply it, and there is also the fact you can find a ghost sleeping in his bed...
[Power Perversion Potential](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PowerPerversionPotential): He's a necrophiliac who practices necromancy. The rest should fall into place from there.

[Stalker with a Crush](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StalkerWithACrush): A very creepy example towards Dawnstar's milkmaids. His journals mention that after being exiled from Dawnstar, he misses them and has wet dreams about them. Then one of them accidentally makes it to Yngvild later and is captured by his minions, leading him to kill her so he can [Leave No Witnesses](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LeaveNoWitnesses). *Then* he finds out he can reanimate her as a ghost, and starts actively sending his minions to abduct more of them from Dawnstar for him to kill and raise...

[Everyone Has Standards](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EveryoneHasStandards): Despite leading an extreme, militant order of monster and Daedra-hunters, even Carcette felt that Isran took things a bit too far with his hatred of vampires.
[Fantastic Racism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism): The sect is not very polite to Orcs, presumably because of their connection to Malacath.

[Healing Hands](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HealingHands): She's the Expert-level Restoration trainer, not that it means much with *Dawnguard* installed, as there's no realistic way to train Restoration up to its cap with her before the Hall of the Vigilant is destroyed. At least Colette Marence will still be around, and Dawnguard-aligned players get Florentius to compensate.

[Killed Offscreen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KilledOffScreen): Everyone in the Hall of the Vigilant, Carcette included, is slain by Volkihar vampires once *Dawnguard* is installed (if the player is level 10 or higher - lower level players and new characters can still visit the hall before it's destroyed).
[Last Stand](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LastStand): If you go to Hall of the Vigilant after it's destroyed, there are several dead vampires and death hounds in the hall, meaning they didn't die easily.

[Sudden Sequel Death Syndrome](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuddenSequelDeathSyndrome): Carcette wasn't too remarkable in the vanilla game, isn't attached to any quests, and there was no indication that the Hall of the Vigilants was under any threat. Then you install *Dawnguard*, and she becomes one of its first casualties.

[Too Dumb to Live](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TooDumbToLive): *Dawnguard* reveals that not only did she not accept that the Volkihar vampires were out of the Vigilants' league, but when warned about it by the leader of the Dawnguard, Carcette ignored him.
[Underestimating Badassery](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnderestimatingBadassery): She and her Vigilant fail to realize the threat represented by the Volkihar vampires, leading to their demise.
[Platonic Life-Partners](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlatonicLifePartners): With his former commander, Brina Merelis.
[Retired Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RetiredBadass): One who comes out of retirement. It takes guts to dust off the old Legion armor in a Stormcloak city when the Jarl wants him executed.

[Undying Loyalty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UndyingLoyalty): To the Legion, and to Brina for shared service time in the Legion. His loyalty is so deep that he openly antagonizes the initial Stormcloak-allied Jarl by dusting off his old Legion armor and wearing it about town.
[Court Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CourtMage): For Dawnstar.

[Mr. Exposition](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MrExposition): You can see her (futilely) trying to convince Silus Vesuius to close his museum, and if you ask her on this afterwards, she can give you a brief introduction to the Mythic Dawn.

[Put on a Bus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PutOnABus): Subverted. The player can listen to her asking the very Stormcloak-allied Jarl to basically do this, and grant her some time away from court, and he very crossly denies the request.

[Shell-Shocked Veteran](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShellShockedVeteran): After taking part in the defense of the Imperial City during the Great War, she's seared, frozen, and electrified far too many young elves for her peace of mind, and is thus pretty much a pacifist. Unfortunately, she's so high-strung from serving under Skald that if the Imperials take Dawnstar and Brina Merelis takes the throne, she tends to assume the worst when Brina asks something of her. The fact that Brina's housecarl Horik doesn't trust her can't be helping, either.

[Avenging the Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AvengingTheVillain): In a way, he seeks to revive interest in the Mythic Dawn cult through his museum and somewhat rehabilitate their image from delusional madmen to noble agents of change.
[Black Shirt](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackShirt): Believes that the Mythic Dawn should be remembered for holding the fate of the Empire within their grasp.
[Call-Back](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CallBack): His entire quest is one to *Oblivion*, being focused around the Mythic Dawn.

[Face Death with Dignity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FaceDeathWithDignity): If you decline his offer of money in exchange for sparing his life and decide to just kill him, he elects to go down fighting and attacks you.

[Genre Blind](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GenreBlind): Frighteningly oblivious to the fact that [Evil Is Not a Toy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilIsNotAToy). He seems to think that he's in a setting where simply collecting pieces of an infamous doomsday cult's weapon is both easy and not that dangerous, despite the fact that the being who gave said weapon still is around and would have followers still. Worse yet, he seemed to believe that Mehrunes Dagon would simply do as he asked with no sacrifice as if the Daedric Princes were little more than benevolent genies.
[Nightmare Fetishist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NightmareFetishist): He seems a little too enthusiastic about the Daedric cult of his ancestors.
[Pet the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PetTheDog): If you  (SPOILER) let him live and he survives the Dremora attack , he'll sincerely thank you for it.

[Sadistic Choice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SadisticChoice):  (SPOILER) You can either betray and kill Silus to get Mehrunes' Razor or spare his life and forfeit the chance to reforge the weapon, leaving you with only the disassembled fragments.

[Socially Unacceptable Collection](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SociallyUnacceptableCollection): He turns his house into a museum dedicated to the Mythic Dawn, the [Apocalypse Cult](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ApocalypseCult) that murdered Emperor Uriel Septim and caused the Oblivion Crisis [200 years prior](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/TheElderScrollsIVOblivion).

[Too Dumb to Live](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TooDumbToLive): He not only tries to find all the fragments of Mehrunes' Razor to complete his collection, but he actually decides to find one of the Dagon's shrines and *ask him to repair it*. You can call him out on the fact that messing with the Daedric Prince of Destruction's [Artifact of Doom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArtifactOfDoom) is a terrible idea, not that he'll listen.  (SPOILER) It may just prove to be his undoing.
[You Have Outlived Your Usefulness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouHaveOutlivedYourUsefulness): Mehrunes Dagon declares this, although it's up to the player whether to actually kill him or not.
[Lazy Bum](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LazyBum): Malur is perfectly content to just sit on his ass and do nothing all day, and bristles at the idea of actually doing any sort of work.
[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): His surname is uncannily close to "Sloth", which is something he proudly is.

tropeName: The Pirates Who Don't Do Anything
tropeNotes:
[The Pirates Who Don't Do Anything](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThePiratesWhoDontDoAnything): His answer if you ask him what he does as a Steward:
QUOTE **Malur:** Me? Nothing. And I hope to keep it that way.

[Professional Butt-Kisser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ProfessionalButtKisser): After doing his Favor Quest, he will teach a level of Speech along with dropping this line:
QUOTE **Malur:** This should come in handy. Here. Let me show you a few tricks I've learned about buttering up royalty.

[Sure, Let's Go with That](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SureLetsGoWithThat): He is just a regular Dark Elf, with no particular experience or knowledge of magic; but because he is an elf, Korir assumed he *must* have ties with the College of Winterhold, and recruited him as a steward. Malur reacted with this trope so he could benefit from the position.

[Affably Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AffablyEvil): The 'evil' part is a bit of a stretch, since Nelacar is personable, helpful, endearing, and very possibly the *nicest* Altmer in the game next to Viarmo. However, he's also probably a necromancer who has done some vile, vile things. Should the Dragonborn have completed the College questline, he respectfully addresses them as "Archmage". Of course, it's [entirely possible](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AlternateCharacterInterpretation) he might simply be trying to get on their good side to be allowed back into the College.

[Dark Is Not Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DarkIsNotEvil): Seems to believe this, as he seems to believe that  (SPOILER) corrupting Azura's Star into the Black Star  is preferable than turning it over to its "evil" Daedric master.

[Everyone Has Standards](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EveryoneHasStandards):
    - He's probably done some vile things during his time, but he personally thinks his former teacher went far too far. - On the other side of the coin, he got himself kicked out of the College of Winterhold somehow, even though the College itself is more tolerant of necromancers than most.

[Evil Smells Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilSmellsBad): Or more specifically, according to Dagur, [like a beast that's](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShoutOut) "[been turned inside-out and exploded](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Film/GalaxyQuest)."

[Necromancer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Necromancer): Probably, given his involvement with Malyn Varen's experiments into immortality and his general comfort with the concept of black soul gems. Conversely, he *did* express being appalled at the lengths to which his former teacher was willing to go when studying Azura's Star.
[Affably Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AffablyEvil): He's nice enough for a madman, but he openly admits that he's done some very nasty things in service to Hermaeus Mora.

[Bunny-Ears Lawyer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BunnyEarsLawyer): Septimus is clearly insane, but he's also the *most* knowledgeable Dwemer researcher we have ever encountered save for Sotha Sil and Vivec who had firsthand knowledge. His ramblings, while odd and seemingly nonsensical, are actually quite close to how the Dwemer perceived the world. Referring to their technology and designs as "musical" in nature and looking at the world in a purely cosmic manner where time and distance aren't as relevant as whether or not something exists at all.
[Cloudcuckoolander](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Cloudcuckoolander): He's a bit eccentric due to having his brain scrambled by Elder Scrolls.
[Deal with the Devil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DealWithTheDevil): He's dealt with Hermaeus Mora due to his thirst for knowledge.
[Eerie Arctic Research Station](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EerieArcticResearchStation): Septimus’s residence is an ice cave far North of Winterhold where he researches a Dwemer box.
[Go Mad from the Isolation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoMadFromTheIsolation): Probably a contributing factor to his insanity, but the main cause of it is that...

[Go Mad from the Revelation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoMadFromTheRevelation): He went insane when he looked upon an Elder Scroll. It's implied that four or more dimensions got crammed into his poor little three-dimensional brain, too.
[The Hermit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHermit): He lives all by himself in a outpost north to Winterhold, which is already far from civilization as it is.
[Junkie Prophet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JunkieProphet): Judging by the empty Skooma bottles at his outpost, it's likely.

[Mind Screw](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MindScrew): His book, *Ruminations on the Elder Scrolls,* shows up in *Online*, which takes place more than a thousand years before the events of *Skyrim*. The Moth Priest who found it in the library stacks noted that the postscript says it came from "4E 195", making him suspect it is a transcription error... but he's not 100% sure on that, considering what he deals with.
    - There's some theories that suggest that he didn't die to (SPOILER) Mora but that he came to the same conclusions about the nature of the universe that Talos did because he (SPOILER) read Mora's book . Unlike Talos, though, he wasn't ready for the truth and thus *ceased to exist completely* instead of gaining godlike powers. This is based on the idea that the daedric gods can't just kill people from beyond their own dimension, because otherwise they wouldn't need Champions and cultists to do the killings for them.

[Mathematician's Answer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MathematiciansAnswer): When asked where one can find an Elder Scroll, he says it is very close... in the sense of being in the same three-dimensional plane as them. Of course, this is actually one of the longer quests in the game, because you can't travel in four dimensions!
[Rhymes on a Dime](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RhymesOnADime): He tends to speak like this.

[Unwitting Pawn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnwittingPawn): Hermaeus Mora's. He *thinks* that Mora's helping him retrieve the Heart of Lorkhan. He's actually being used by Mora to unleash the *[Oghma Infinium](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TomeOfEldritchLore)* on the world.
[Third-Person Person](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThirdPersonPerson): He sporadically refers to himself with his own name, likely due to his insanity.

[Villain of Another Story](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainOfAnotherStory): He admits to doing horrible things in the service of  (SPOILER)  Hermaeus Mora  such as murder and spreading plagues. He also came into contact with an Elder Scrolls at some point in the past which damaged his mind.

[You Have Outlived Your Usefulness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouHaveOutlivedYourUsefulness):  (SPOILER) Due to his insanity, Hermaeus Mora no longer considers him useful and he turns into a pile of ash upon finding the *Oghma Infinium*.

[Artifact Title](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArtifactTitle): In-universe example. M'aiq the Liar served as an [Author Avatar](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AuthorAvatar) giving cryptic [Take Thats](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakeThat) right from his introduction in *Morrowind*, but the *in-universe* untruthfulness of (most of) his comments were toned down for *Oblivion* and *Skyrim*.
QUOTE **M'aiq:** Some say Alduin is Akatosh. Some say M'aiq is a liar. Don't you believe either of those things.

[Author Avatar](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AuthorAvatar): The only reason he has a role in the game is to voice the creators' opinion about the [Unpleasable Fanbase](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnpleasableFanbase).

[Beware the Silly Ones](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BewareTheSillyOnes): One possible variant of his encounter can consist of finding him standing next to a burned cart, several dead human bodies, and the corpse of *a dragon*.

[Catchphrase](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CatchPhrase): Averted. He sometimes does utter the catchphrase of his ancestor ("M'aiq knows much, tells some. M'aiq knows many things others do not."), but does not use enough to make it his own catchphrase.

[Cloudcuckoolander](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Cloudcuckoolander): He comes across as very detached from the setting. Logical, since he is something of a literal [Author Avatar](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AuthorAvatar).
[Deadpan Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker): Some of his speeches are very sarcastic.

[Easter Egg](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EasterEgg): As a [Meta Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MetaGuy) [Fourth-Wall Observer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FourthWallObserver) who runs randomly around Skyrim. It's entirely possible to play for hours without running into him, and his dialogue is mostly just for fun.

[Legacy Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LegacyCharacter): There was also a Khajiit with his name 206 years earlier in Morrowind and 200 years earlier in Cyrodiil. This is explained by the fact that the name is passed down to newer generations.
QUOTE  **M'aiq:** M'aiq's father was also called M'aiq. As was M'aiq's father's father. At least, that's what his father said.
[Mushroom Samba](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MushroomSamba): He always has Skooma on his person, which might explain his bizarre, if fairly accurate, view of the world.

[Noodle Incident](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoodleIncident): He was [soul-trapped once](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YourSoulIsMine) and didn't appreciate the experience. Come the *Dawnguard* expansion and the reveal of the Soul Cairn, a not-very-nice place where trapped souls end up, it's not hard to see why.
[Take That!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakeThat): Just about every speech he makes is a reaction the makers have about an aspect of the game fans aren't pleased about.

[Take That Us](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakeThatUs): He also starts snarking at some minor gripes concerning *Oblivion*. A noteworthy snark is when he repeats a much ridiculed line about mudcrabs from the previous game. He also mocks several bits about Skyrim's lack of immersion in spots, such as the supposed 7,000 steps.
[Third-Person Person](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThirdPersonPerson): Like most Khajiit, M'aiq talks about M'aiq in this fashion almost every time M'aiq speaks.

[Unusually Uninteresting Sight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnusuallyUninterestingSight): For whatever reason, he won't attack the player if they're in Vampire Lord, or Beast Form, nor will he attack the player if they're a stage four vampire.

[Video Game Cruelty Potential](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VideoGameCrueltyPotential): M'aiq is marked as essential and isn't affiliated with anyone, meaning that he can be assaulted to grind your combat skills with no repercussions.

[Death Seeker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathSeeker): He has seen a vision from Malacath telling him to seek a glorious death. By the time the Dragonborn gets to him, he's surrounded by saber cat corpses. Apparently, they weren't glorious enough.

[Dying Moment of Awesome](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DyingMomentOfAwesome): From his point of view, his death at the hands of the player counts. Especially if the latter's Dragonborn identity has been revealed. And *especially* especially if you have already completed Malacath's Daedric Quest: that way, not only does the Old Orc die in battle as he wanted, but *he also dies at the hands of a legendary dragonslayer who was acknowledged by Malacath himself as his Champion*. Bonus points if you use Volendrung, Malacath's own artifact weapon, during the battle.

tropeName: Exactly What It Says on the Tin
tropeNotes: [Exactly What It Says on the Tin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ExactlyWhatItSaysOnTheTin): His character name is just "Old Orc." And that's exactly what he is!

[Face Death with Dignity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FaceDeathWithDignity): He explains that he wishes to die while he can "still call himself a proper man", elaborating that he doesn't want to linger on to the point where he's frail and feeble. He further explains that it's "unseemly" to cling to something after it becomes useless, even more so when that thing is yourself.

[Honor Before Reason](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HonorBeforeReason): He's honestly not *that* old, but he's past his prime in traditional Orc culture. Even though you can tell him this, and point out his potential usefulness to others outside the strongholds, he still insists on dying because Malacath wills it.
[I Cannot Self-Terminate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ICannotSelfTerminate): If asked, he'll clarify that he can't kill himself because "it would displease Malacath."
[Old Soldier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OldSoldier): Fittingly. He's also fairly tough as NPCs go; if you encounter him at a low level, it's probably in your best interest to just ignore him.
[Video Game Cruelty Potential](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VideoGameCrueltyPotential): There's nothing that stops the Dragonborn from using Soul Trap on him.

[Hypocrite](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Hypocrite): The Khajiit caravans are not allowed inside any of the cities, because the Nords think them to be thieves and smugglers. Ri'saad laments this "racist" attitude... except he openly sells illegal Moon Sugar and Skooma.  (SPOILER) Join the Thieves' Guild, and one mission shows that Ri'saad and his caravans willingly smuggle goods and act as fences for little more than a few bribes.

tropeName: My Species Doth Protest Too Much
tropeNotes: [My Species Doth Protest Too Much](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MySpeciesDothProtestTooMuch): Though the Khajiit Kingdoms of Elsweyr joined the Aldmeri Dominion willingly, he regards Khajiit working with the Thalmor poorly, calling them "Thalmor Filth" and noting that they give all Khajiit a bad name.

[Nice Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceGuy): He (if you talk to the other Khajiit merchants) was the guy who helped them all carve out a lucrative trading niche in the economy of Skyrim, and he even took a few with troubled backgrounds and made them respectable. Ysolda of Whiterun, who wishes to be a shopkeeper, also states that despite their reputation, the Khajiit are fairly honest businessmen by her account.

[Then Let Me Be Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThenLetMeBeEvil): A possible way to look at him being a fence for the guild and selling moon sugar. If he's going to be shunned anyway, he might as well make a profit from it...

[Cultured Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CulturedBadass): One version of his appearance code brings a pair of bandits along with him, both of whom he beats quite handily. Of course, since he's marked an essential NPC, it's basically impossible for him to lose. At higher levels, he can be found going one on one against Frost Trolls and even *dragons*.

[Noodle Incident](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoodleIncident): One where it's pretty easy to fill in the blanks. You can ask him to train you in Speech, but he'll politely refuse, saying, "Ah. Well. After a little incident with a roguish lad and the daughter of a prominent thane... Well, let's just say, best not."

[Break the Haughty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreakTheHaughty): [Downplayed](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DownplayedTrope) with Plautis in their post-wedding encounter. While still not exactly friendly, he admits they lost everything they brought with them and just wants to find his way out of Skyrim.

[Brick Joke](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrickJoke): After completing "Bound Until Death", they can still be found wandering Skyrim as lost as ever, but after having fallen upon quite a bit of bad luck as well.

[Call-Back](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CallBack): One or both of them are likely descendants of Narina Carvain, the ruler of Bruma in *[Oblivion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/TheElderScrollsIVOblivion)*.

[Humiliation Conga](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HumiliationConga): According to Plautis post-"Bound Until Death",  (SPOILER) they were beset by bandits, his clothes were shredded by a Sabre Cat, and a dragon ate the Legionnaire acting as their bodyguard .

[Jerkass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Jerkass): If you try to engage them in dialogue, you'll quickly find them to be anything but friendly. Salonia takes the cake post-wedding, referring to the Dragonborn as "[it](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItIsDehumanizing)" and swearing to hire an army of battlemages to burn Skyrim to ashes once they get back to Cyrodiil for their misfortunes.

[No Sense of Direction](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoSenseOfDirection): If you follow them for long enough, they arrive not at Solitude, but Windhelm. And since they can be encountered multiple times, it can be assumed that this has been going on for a while.

[Professional Butt-Kisser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ProfessionalButtKisser): The whole point of their visit is to ingratiate themselves with Vittoria, establish a business deal with the East Empire Trading Company, and eventually land an audience with Emporer Titus Mede II for some unspecified reason.

[Skewed Priorities](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SkewedPriorities): While Plautis laments their near-deadly troubles with  (SPOILER) bandits and wildlife , Salonia is angriest about ruining her favorite shoes.

[Unsympathetic Comedy Protagonist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnsympatheticComedyProtagonist): Minus the "protagonist" part. They're not that likable, and everything about their encounters is in service of comic relief.
[Upper-Class Twit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UpperClassTwit): They're rich snobs from Cyrodiil that look down on the Dragonborn.

[Video Game Cruelty Potential](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VideoGameCrueltyPotential): Pre-"Bound Until Death", they carry several valuable gems and necklaces meant for Vittoria, and dialogue provides the Dragonborn the opportunity to attempt to rob them, turning the bodyguard hostile.
[Arc Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArcVillain): All three of them, for the quest "Forbidden Legend."

[Barrier Change Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BarrierChangeBoss): Jyrik surrounds himself in an elemental cloak that gives him heavy resistance to either fire, frost, or shock. You'll have to use one of the other elements to beat him ([or just bash his face in with a weapon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakeAThirdOption)).

[Boss Rush](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BossRush): At the end of their quest, all three brothers reappear to fight you in succession.  (SPOILER) Once beaten again, they prepare to all attack you at once, but [Gauldur's spirit puts an end to that](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigDamnHeroes).
[Doppelgänger Spin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DoppelgangerSpin): Throughout his fight, Sigdis will periodically create clones of himself that can attack with both arrows and Shouts.

[Fighter, Mage, Thief](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FighterMageThief): Mikrul is the Fighter, as he attacks you up close with a gaggle of Draugr flunkies, and carries the health-boosting piece of the amulet. Sigdis peppers you with arrows from long range, and his piece of the amulet gives a stamina boost, making him the Thief. Jyrik wields magic to protect himself and attack you, and his amulet piece boosts the magic stat, so he's the Mage.

[Final Boss Preview](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FinalBossPreview): When encountered, Jyrik will draw power from the Eye of Magnus to make himself invulnerable until Tolfdir starts draining that power away. At the end of the College questline,  (SPOILER) Ancano  uses the same strategy and must be defeated the same way.

[Flunky Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlunkyBoss): Mikrul fights accompanied by a number of Draugr Thralls. They're exceedingly weak, unarmed, and die when Mikrul himself goes down, so they're not much of a problem, and an archer Dragonborn can actually take Mikrul out before he has the chance to summon most or even all of them from their tombs.

tropeName: Kinslaying Is a Special Kind of Evil
tropeNotes: [Kinslaying Is a Special Kind of Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KinslayingIsASpecialKindOfEvil): Between their reign of terror, and their murder of their father to obtain his Amulet, the Sons of Gauldur were [damned from history](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnPerson) by King Harald.

[MacGuffin Guardian](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MacGuffinGuardian): Each holds a piece of Gauldur's amulet. Jyrik pulls double duty by also guarding the Eye of Magnus in the College of Winterhold questline, making him the one you're most likely to encounter first if you don't actively pursue the quest.

[Magic Staff](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicStaff): Jyrik's staff possesses a unique shock spell that burns magicka equal to *double* its damage; most other shock spells burn a lesser or equal amount to the damage dealt. However, he doesn't actually use it; it's instead lying on a table in front of him.

[Mass "Oh, Crap!"](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MassOhCrap):  (SPOILER) When Archmage Gauldur's spirit rises from his grave behind them, the brothers can only [exclaim his name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SayMyName) before he banishes their souls for good.

[Mutual Kill](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MutualKill): The fate of the living Sigdis Gauldurson, in battle with King Harald's personal battlemage Geirmund. There's a reason why the tomb where Sigdis is found and the lake it sits in the middle of are both named for Geirmund.
[Self-Made Orphan](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SelfMadeOrphan): They conspired together to murder their father in order to claim the power of an enchanted amulet he created for themselves.

[Un-person](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnPerson): To ensure that the lure of the Gauldur Amulet would never lead to more bloodshed, High King Harald had Gauldur and his sons' names erased from all records. His efforts ultimately did not stand up to the resolve of Daynas Valen, who cobbled the details back together over his lifetime in his pursuit of the amulet for himself.

[The Ghost](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheGhost): Does not make a direct appearance in the game that we know of. It's been theorized that she's either Drascua in Hag Rock Redoubt/Dead Crone Rock (who is encountered and fought during the unrelated Daedric Quest "Pieces of the Past") or the unnamed Hagraven in Hag's End/Deepwood Redoubt (which contains a bonus you can earn on  (SPOILER) Gaius Maro 's contract in the Dark Brotherhood questline). Both are Hagravens that are surrounded by large Forsworn Camps. The latter of the two is unique in she's also surrounded by a coven of Hags and Witches and she will teleport to a different room after she's taken enough damage. In Deepwood Redoubt there's also a missive that details that the Matriach had the Forsworn head there.
[Greater-Scope Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GreaterScopeVillain): Madanach puts a face to the organization, but she's the one in real power behind the scenes.
[One Bad Mother](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneBadMother): She goes by "The Matriarch", and she's the leader of the Forsworn as a whole.
[The Woman Behind the Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheWomanBehindTheMan): She's issuing orders to the Forsworn behind the scenes (or at least to some of the Forsworn cells around the Reach).
